This includes the issue of attribution (who conducted the cyber-operation), tracking it back not just to a state (or non-state actor/hacker group working for the state), but potentially to a particular ‘computer … to identify the person who operated the computer, and more importantly to identify the real mastermind’ behind the attack.[65]\nAttribution may be a challenge for all crimes, but particularly so for conduct in cyberspace. Not only do cyber-attackers sometimes go to considerable lengths to conceal cyber-operations,[66] states have at times deliberately hidden their cyber-operations as perpetrated by another state ('false-flagging'). This, for example, happened when 'Russian hackers piggy-backed on an Iranian cyber-espionage operation', thereby reportedly hacking into 'government and industry organizations in dozens of countries while masquerading as attackers from the Islamic Republic [of Iran].[67] Or states can hide behind non-state actors to mask their operations.[68] Even when that is not the case, cyber-operations can be difficult to attribute because they can be perpetrated through a single computer or network of computers located far from where the consequences impact, and also can be concealed by feigning that operating systems are functioning normally.[69] Furthermore, if attribution is to be made, this raises questions as to who would be in a position to do so. Will it be practical for the ICC to do this by itself? And, if not, what are the implications of relying on state cooperation in this regard?\nFor Rome Statute purposes, proof of attribution would need to be demonstrated through admissible evidence[70] and this will require authentication; moreover, simply assembling a cyber-case would be extremely complex. There would need to be evidence gathering[71] (on both the IT and operational technology (OT) sides), chain of custody would need to be established, and, furthermore, the victim might believe the issue is just a glitch in the system\n\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nrather than immediately recognize they have been subjected to an 'attack'. The OTP would need to develop significant technical expertise as would, eventually, Chambers, Defense counsel, and other participants in the ICC judicial process. This knowledge could be internally developed through hiring and/or the use of outside experts; yet, all of this might be very difficult to organize without excellent state cooperation. The more that cyber investigatory capacities of the ICC increase, the more important will it be for the court to have in place protections safeguarding privacy and related digital rights; the ICC will thus need (and probably should already have) a privacy policy and data protection standards that are binding on the institution.72\n## C. Issues of Jurisdiction\nWhile questions of jurisdiction merit a far more extensive analysis, it is worth initially observing that a cyber-operation may often be launched from one state (the 'attacker' state), where the operations originated, with consequences (or 'effects')73 felt in one or more (even many) 'victim' states. Absent a Security Council referral, either the 'attacker' state or 'victim' state would need to be a state party to the Rome Statute, or the perpetrators would need to be nationals of a state party — because the Rome Statute gives the ICC jurisdiction over the nationals of, and crimes committed on the territory of, states parties.74 In this latter regard, the Pre-Trial Chamber's ruling in the Myanmar/Bangladesh situation holds that at least one element of the crime must have been committed on the territory of a state party for ICC jurisdiction to exist.75\nWhere many states are impacted, the question arises whether even a modest amount of impact (effects) in one ICC state party would suffice to give the ICC jurisdiction, or whether some kind of threshold must be satisfied — and, if so, whether this threshold may be satisfied collectively if multiple states are affected, and whether they would all have to be ICC states parties? For example, if the attack produces consequences in ten states but only one is an ICC state party, would that suffice to create jurisdiction if the effects in the one state party do not independently satisfy the threshold but the effects in the ten states would do so? The preliminary answer from the ICC appears to be in the affirmative. In the Comoros situation, the Pre-Trial Chamber confirmed its view\n\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1149\nthat conduct occurring outside the jurisdictional reach of the Court may be taken into account for the purpose of gravity analysis. The OTP agrees with this and has proposed the test that such extra-jurisdictional conduct must be ‘rationally and adequately’ linked to the crimes that are within the jurisdiction of the Court in order to be taken into account.\nThere is also the question of the transit of an attack through the servers of a third state party or multiple third states parties (also referred to as the ‘routing state(s)’). The Tallinn experts (while opining on jurisdiction more generally and not ICC jurisdiction) suggested that in such a situation there would be only a ‘minimal connection with cyber infrastructure on that state’s territory’. The Tallinn experts differentiated a situation where cyber infrastructure in the third state is taken over, which they conclude could create jurisdiction because the ‘use of such compromised cyber infrastructure [would not be] de minimis’. If the ICC were to take an analogous approach, use of cyber infrastructure in a third state that is an ICC state party potentially could create ICC jurisdiction, although mere transit through the servers of a third state party might not do so.\nThe crime of aggression has a different and more complex jurisdictional regime. Crimes committed by non-state party nationals or on the territory of a non-state party are completely excluded from ICC jurisdiction. As to states parties, it depends on how one reads the Kampala amendment and the Activating Resolution that activated crime of aggression jurisdiction. The ‘Intent’ Requirement and Unintended Consequences\nGiven that several cyber-operations to date have proliferated well-beyond their intended targets, another question is whether the Rome Statute would have any applicability for unintended results; here, one might consider both (1) unintended and foreseeable consequences, and (2) unintended and unforeseeable consequences. These issues were considered by the Tallinn experts in terms of responsibility more generally (not in the Rome Statute context). The Rome Statute appears to take a fairly restrictive approach with its requirements of ‘intent’ and ‘knowledge’ in Article 30. Article 30(2) specifies that ‘intent’ exists when (1) a ‘person means to engage in the conduct’ or (2) ‘is aware that [the consequences] will occur in the ordinary course of events’. ‘Knowledge’ is defined as awareness that a ‘circumstance exists’ or ‘a consequence will occur in the ordinary course of events’. While there is some support for including notions such as conscious risk-taking or recklessness, the ‘leading view in the early practice of the ICC’ takes a ‘restrictive interpretation’. Thus, ‘[t]he Lubanga appeal judgment confirmed the interpretation put forward in the Bemba decision on the confirmation of charges, that under Article 30 … “the standard for the foreseeability of events is virtual certainty”’.\n United Nations Treaty Collection, Ch. XVIII, Penal Matters, ‘Amendments on the Crime of Aggression to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court’, as of 18 January 2021, available online at https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XVIII-10-b&amp;chapter=18⟨=en (visited 30 January 2021).\n See Arts 13(b), 15ter ICCSt. For background on Security Council referrals and the crime of aggression, see J. Trahan, ‘Revisiting the Role of the Security Council Regarding the International Criminal Court’s Crime of Aggression’, 17 Journal of International Criminal Justice (2019) 471.\n See supra note 7 (Ukraine).\n See Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 343, §§ 13–14 (considering reasonably foreseeable consequences versus unexpected results).\n Art. 30(2)(a)-(b) ICCSt.\n Art. 30(3) ICCSt.\n Case Matrix Network, Art. 30(2)(b), Intent in Relation to Result (Mohamed Elewa Badar and Sara Porro, authors) updated 18 August 2017.\n Ibid. (citing Judgment on the Appeal of Mr. Thomas Lubanga Dyilo Against His Conviction, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-A-5), Appeals Chamber, 1 December 2014, § 441 et seq; Decision Pursuant to Article 61(7)(a) and (b) of the Rome Statute on the Charges of the Prosecutor Against Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo, Bemba (ICC-01/05-01/08-424), Pre-Trial Chamber, 15 June 2009, § 359 et seq). Other cases also endorse this ‘virtual certainty’ standard: see Judgment, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-3121-Red A5), Appeals Chamber, 1 December 2014, § 447; Judgment Pursuant to Article 74 of the Statute, Katanga (ICC-01/04-01/07-3436), Trial Chamber II, 7 March 2014, §§ 776–777.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1151\nIf ICC jurisprudence remains consistent with that approach, responsibility would not attach to unforeseeable consequences, and even as to foreseeable consequences, the threshold would be quite high — ‘virtual certainty’ that the consequences will result. For example, imagine a dam above a city is penetrated and water released flooding a city below the dam. Under the Lubanga/Bemba standard, responsibility would only attach for flooding the city if there were ‘virtual certainty’ of that consequence. (By contrast, the ad hoc tribunals found there was responsibility for ‘reasonably foreseeable’ crimes when applying ‘joint criminal enterprise’ (type 3).) While a strong argument can be made that recklessness should sometimes rise to the level of intent (and some older ICC Pre-Trial decisions take that approach), it does not seem to be the ICC’s primary approach, nor does the ICC appear to adopt the standard of ‘reasonable foreseeability’. ‘Intentional endangerment’ arguably should, however, create individual criminal responsibility and the ICC’s states parties might consider a Rome Statute amendment to expressly encompass it as satisfying the intent requirement. Note also that domestic courts, as mentioned, as well as other international or hybrid tribunals are not limited by the Rome Statute’s standards — so the Rome Statute’s failure to encompass ‘recklessness’ does not mean that it is displaced in international criminal law more generally. Thus, the requirements in Article 30 of ‘intent’ and ‘knowledge’ could prove an additional limiting factor, excluding criminal responsibility for unforeseeable results and setting a high standard as to foreseeable results, requiring ‘virtual certainty’ of the consequences.\n## E. Thus, one would either need to 'fit' the cyber-operation in question into the Statute's existing structure or not. Arguing about the similarities between a physical/kinetic attack and a cyber-operation, for example, may not suffice, because it would be suggesting application by analogy. This limitation and the presumption that ambiguity favours the defendant, however, does not mean that one could not give an updated, modern reading to Rome Statute provisions. Law, to serve a useful purpose, should meet contemporary challenges. Furthermore, the Rome Statute is generally 'weapons neutral' or 'technology neutral' — one applies the crimes regardless of the particular weapon or technology utilized; viewed in this light, cyber is simply akin to a new weapon or technology system.\nThus, the above discussion suggests the potentially applicability of the Rome Statute to a limited subset of cyber-operations (1) if they meet the Rome Statute's gravity threshold; (2) where attribution could be proven, eventually, beyond a reasonable doubt; (3) where jurisdiction exists; (4) where 'intent' can be demonstrated (which appears to exclude responsibility for unforeseen consequences and limit responsibility even for foreseen consequences); and (5) where the harm caused falls within the definition of a Rome Statute crime without drawing upon analogies, with ambiguity construed to favour the defence.\n# 4. Consideration of the Rome Statute's Substantive Crimes\nThe next section briefly overviews how the Rome Statute's four crimes might apply to certain cyber-operations, and outlines the key elements of each. The author does not suggest this is a comprehensive discussion; rather, this overview clarifies that at least a limited subset of cyber-operations could fall within the ambit of the Rome Statute's crimes.\n# A. Cyber-Operations as War Crimes under the Rome Statute\nAs mentioned, the Tallinn Manual 2.0 takes as its starting point that a cyber-operation can constitute a use of force. The Tallinn Manuals further take the view that, in a state of armed conflict (whether international armed conflict or non-international armed conflict), all the rules of international humanitarian law apply in the cyber-domain. The ICJ’s holding in the Nuclear Weapons case reinforces this as the court maintained that IHL applies to ‘all forms of warfare and to all kinds of weapons’. Cyber-operations may be employed during and in the context of an already existing armed conflict or they (either alone or in conjunction with conventional weapons) might, in theory, create the state of armed conflict. If cyber-operations are subject to IHL, then, for example, they may not target civilians or be targeted indiscriminately (both of which would violate the principle of distinction), and may not cause excessive ‘collateral damage’ (which would violate the principle of proportionality). Additionally, for a war crimes case, all the contextual elements would need to be proven — such as the existence of an ‘armed conflict’ (whether international or non-international), a ‘nexus’ between the cyber-operation and the armed conflict, and the awareness of the perpetrator of the factual circumstances that established the existence of the armed conflict. These attacks were ‘blended attacks’, perpetrated through cyber and physical/kinetic means. The armed conflict there has killed more than 10,000 people, and, in addition to conventional military bombardments, included hacking into dozens of governmental organizations and companies through a ‘scorched-earth’ cyber-attack that affected victims ranging from media outlets, to railway firms and hospitals, causing hundreds of thousands of homes to lose electricity and shutting down at least three regional utilities. Both the United States and the UK take the view that the cyber-attacks on Ukraine were perpetrated by Russia’s military intelligence service, commonly known by the Russian acronym GRU. Such cyber-operations conducted during a state of armed conflict could, if all the elements of the crimes were proven, potentially constitute the war crime of intentionally directing attacks against the civilian population, or launching a disproportionate attack, wherein incidental loss of life or injury to civilians is ‘clearly excessive in relationship to the concrete and direct overall military advantage anticipated’. The cyber-operations also appear to have been ‘indiscriminate’. A cyber-operation against a medical facility could also constitute a war crime under Rome Statute Articles 8(2)(b)(xxiv) or (e)(ii). Cyber-operations as Crimes against Humanity under the Rome Statute\nThe hallmark requirements for crimes against humanity are acts ‘committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack directed against any civilian population, with knowledge of the attack’. Article 7(2)(a) defines the ‘attack’ against the civilian population as ‘a course of conduct involving the multiple commission of acts [enumerated in Article 7(1)] against any civilian population, pursuant to or in furtherance of a State or organizational policy to commit such attack’. The ‘attack’ needed to prove ‘crimes against humanity’ need not be a military attack; in fact, the hallmark of crimes against humanity is that the attack is directed against a civilian population and need not be linked to armed conflict. Cyber-operations as Genocide under the Rome Statute\nIn the same way that a cyber-operation that targets persons in particular protected groups could constitute the crime against humanity of persecution, genocide is a crime that targets members of a distinct ‘national, ethnical, racial or religious group’. As to the crime of genocide, it is not the attack itself, but the intent behind the attack that is the crux of the crime. Thus, for the *dolus specialis* (special mental state requirement) of genocide to be satisfied, there must be proof of: (1) ‘intent to destroy’, (2) ‘in whole or in part’, (3) a ‘national ethnical, racial or religious group’, (4) ‘as such’ (i.e. because individuals belong to such a group). The ICC Elements of Crimes also require — at least for non-inchoate forms of responsibility — proof that ‘[t]he conduct took place in the context of a manifest pattern of similar conduct directed against that group or was conduct that could itself effect such destruction’. See e.g. ICC Elements of Crimes, supra note 108, Art. 6(a) Genocide by killing, Element 4.\n For background on how the killing was incited by radio-broadcasts, see e.g. J.F. Metzi, ‘Rwandan Genocide and the International Law of Radio Jamming’, 91 American Journal of International Law (1997) 628.\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\ncyber-operation or a blended cyber and physical/kinetic attack. For example, one might imagine members of a protected group being identified or monitored through cyber technology, or the use of cyber means to incite genocide, with the killing committed through physical/kinetic means. (These might be examples of cyber-enabled genocide.) One could also imagine a cyber-initiated nuclear meltdown that kills a large number of members of another national group (i.e. those in another state).\n## D. Cyber-operations as the Crime of Aggression under the Rome Statute\nWhile the crime of aggression has numerous requirements and warrants a far more extensive discussion, it is crucial to establish, inter alia, a state's 'act of aggression' constitutes a 'manifest' violation of the UN Charter by its 'character, gravity and scale'. The 'act of aggression' is defined as 'use of armed force by a State against the sovereignty, territorial integrity or political\n One could imagine infiltrating people's genetic/medical information — collected by doctors, hospitals, insurance companies, or governments — for members of the genocidal group to use to identify and attack members of the protected group. Author conversation with Noah Weisbord, 13 August 2020; see also Roscini, supra note 33, at 251 (suggesting the example of a 'network intrusion to acquire the names of individuals registered as a certain race' as part of committing genocide, citing Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 66). Or one could imagine using facial recognition and other biometric data to track members of the protected group — as is already happening with the Uighurs in China — and group members then targeted for physical destruction. Author conversation with Noah Weisbord, 13 August 2020; see e.g. C. Buckley and P. Mozur, 'How China Uses High-Tech Surveillance to Subdue Minorities', N.Y. Times (22 May 2019), available online at https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/22/world/asia/china-surveillance-xinjiang.html (visited 30 January 2021). See also 'China Forces Birth Control on Uighurs to Suppress Population', Associated Press (29 June 2020), available online at https://apnews.com/article/e2674c069d46f6d5c9a3d3be40d612d4 (visited 30 January 2021).\n See e.g. P. Mozur, 'A Genocide Incited on Facebook, With Posts from Myanmar's Military', N.Y. Times (15 October 2018), available online at https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/15/technology/myanmar-facebook-genocide.html (visited 30 January 2021). Mozur writes: They posed as fans of pop stars and national heroes as they flooded Facebook with their hatred. One said Islam was a global threat to Buddhism. Another shared a false story about the rape of a Buddhist woman by a Muslim man... The Facebook posts were not from everyday internet users. Instead, they were from Myanmar military personnel who turned the social network into a tool for ethnic cleansing, according to former military officials, researchers and civilian officials in the country.\n Probably for all Rome Statute crimes, the crime could be cyber-enabled — with cyber-operations playing a role, but not necessarily being the main or predominant means whereby the crime is committed. Given this, and the extensive number of cyber-operations occurring, the need for the ICC to develop expertise regarding cyber and to consider issues such as establishing admissibility appears all the more urgent.\n See Roscini, supra note 33, at 250 (providing the example of a cyber-attack that shuts down the cooling system of a nuclear power reactor releasing high levels of radiation and killing members of a particular national group, if one could prove genocidal intent; also suggesting these facts could constitute a crime against humanity).\n Art. 8bis(2) ICCSt.\n Art. 8bis(1) ICCSt.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1161\nindependence of another State, or in any other manner inconsistent with the Charter of the United Nations'.155 Article 8bis(2) enumerates a list of acts that could meet this requirement,156 but each would additionally need to constitute a 'manifest' violation of the UN Charter.157 Another requirement is that the crime only covers 'leaders' in that it applies only to 'person[s] in a position effectively to exercise control over or to direct the political or military actions of a State'.158 Also, the leader would need to engage in the 'planning, preparation, initiation or execution' of the crime.159\nAccordingly, considering a cyber-operation as a potential crime of aggression, this would only apply where: (1) jurisdiction exists; (2) there is a 'manifest' Charter violation — in other words, perhaps not just any Article 2(4) violation (an unlawful 'use of force') but probably something more like an 'armed attack' (and/or an attack that is 'super clear' in terms of its illegality);160 (3) the crime will generally only cover acts of a state, as there are several references in the text to armed force 'by a State' or 'by the armed forces of a State' — although it could potentially cover non-state actors if the leader 'initiates', 'plans', or 'prepares' the act of aggression by employing non-state actors (hacker groups) and the acts of the non-state actors are attributable to the state;161 (4) the suspect is a person who satisfies the 'leadership clause'\n\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\n(probably one of a limited set of top military or political leaders and/or those at the apex of cyber command structures); (5) such leader can be proven to have played a role in planning, preparing, initiating, or executing the cyber-operation; and (6) attribution to the suspect, and their intent and knowledge, could otherwise be proven through admissible evidence that satisfies ‘proof beyond a reasonable doubt’.\nWhile the above requirements appear difficult to satisfy, the fourth act enumerated as potentially qualifying as an ‘act of aggression’ is ‘[a]n attack by the armed forces of a State on the land, sea or air forces, or marine and air fleets of another State’, and Article 8bis(2)(b) refers to ‘the use of any weapon by a State against the territory of another State’. The Tallinn Manual explains how and when a cyber-operation could qualify as an ‘armed attack’, and this could potentially satisfy that definition, particularly if the cyber-operation is committed by the armed forces of a state. One would additionally need to attribute responsibility to a particular leader (or head of cyber command) ‘in a position effectively to exercise control over or to direct the political or military actions of a State’, who planned, prepared, initiated, or played a role in the execution of the cyber-operation. Potentially, as mentioned, the leader could have employed non-state actors (hacker groups) to carry out the operation if their acts are attributable to, or adopted by, the state. The cyber-operation would need to constitute a ‘manifest’ violation of the UN Charter, excluding an operation that is de minimis (insufficient in gravity and/or scale) and/or unclear in terms of its legality/illegality. Yet, because of seemingly extensive jurisdictional limitations — if they are valid — it could be quite difficult to trigger ICC jurisdiction, absent Security Council referral. Here, the specific (and restrictive) jurisdictional regime regarding the crime of aggression (lex specialis) probably overrides the general ICC case law (issued in the context of jurisdiction as to genocide, crimes against humanity, and war crimes) according to which only one element of the crime need to have occurred on the territory of a state party in order to create jurisdiction (lex generalis).\n See supra notes 80-85 and accompanying text (jurisdiction for crime of aggression).\n Art. 8bis(2)(d), ICCSt.\n Art. 8bis(2)(b), ICCSt. (emphasis added).\n See K.L. Miller, ‘The Kampala Compromise and Cyberattacks: Can There be an International Crime of Cyber-Aggression?’, 23 Southern California Interdisciplinary Law Journal (2014) 217, at 235 (‘armed’ force could mean ‘all forms of military-sponsored or state-sponsored uses of force’).\n See supra note 161 (attribution).\n The eight factors used in the Tallinn Manual to evaluate when there is a cyber ‘use of force’ could prove useful. See supra note 32 and accompanying text (severity, immediacy, etc.).\n See supra notes 80-84 and accompanying text.\n See Trahan, supra note 44.\n See Bangladesh/Myanmar Decision, supra note 75 and accompanying text. Thus, for example, as to the crime of aggression, even if one element of the crime occurred on the territory of an ICC state party (e.g. at NATO headquarters in Belgium), that would not create jurisdiction over the actions of nationals of a non-state party at NATO headquarters, because the general Rome Statute rules on jurisdiction would be displaced by the more specific regime regarding\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1163\nAgain returning to the example of cyber-election interference, and considering it in terms of the crime of aggression, election interference certainly could be considered an attack against ‘sovereignty’, covered by Article 8bis(2). Yet, it is questionable whether the interference rises to the level of a ‘manifest’ Charter violation, required by Article 8bis(1). Furthermore, regardless of whether all other elements of the crime could be met, at least one state alleged to be significantly involved in election interference, the Russian Federation, is not a state party to the Rome Statute, so there would be no ICC jurisdiction over the crime of aggression by Russian nationals whether committed on the territory of the United States or within the territories of other Rome Statute states parties. Again, the author’s analysis does not imply there should be no ramifications for such election interference. It should also be recalled that national legislation implementing the crime of aggression could omit the ‘manifest’ requirement and would not be restricted by the Rome Statute’s jurisdictional limitations, so could still encompass election interference as the crime of aggression or in some other manner.\n# 5. Conclusion\nThis article has only touched the surface of what will need to be a far more extensive study of how the crimes in the ICC’s Rome Statute could potentially encompass cyber-operations. Much has been written by cyber experts on the application of the laws of war to cyber operations and on how IHL violations can create war crimes exposure; that body of writing alone clearly suggests the Rome Statute’s potential applicability. As mentioned, an expert report by the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare will contribute further to exploring these important topics.\nWhile the ICC’s cases to date have primarily concerned atrocity crimes committed in less economically developed areas, a role for the Court in addressing even a limited subset of cyber-operations might help to reinforce\nthe crime of aggression, which provides there is no jurisdiction regarding the nationals of non-states parties. See Art. 15bis(5), ICCSt.\n See e.g. S.J. Schakelford, ‘The Law of Cyber Peace’, 18 Chicago Journal of International Law (2017) 11 (quoting the Nicaragua case, supra note 39 (as a matter of sovereignty, nations have an obligation not to interfere in one another’s domestic affairs if that intervention relates to ‘the choice of a political, economic, social, and cultural system’); Efrony and Shany, supra note 3, at 640 (discussing how cyber-operations can violate sovereignty); Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 17 (‘Rule 4: A State must not conduct cyber operations that violate the sovereignty of another State’).\n See Efrony and Shany, supra note 3, at 609–617 (discussing cyber election interference by the Russian Federation).\n Art. 15bis(5) ICCSt.\n See supra note 2.\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nits relevance for states with developed economies — all of which (along with states with developing economies) are experiencing an enormous number of cyber-attacks. Accordingly, various states parties to the Rome Statute may welcome the recognition that certain cyber-operations could constitute Rome Statute crimes, and support the ICC’s addressing of such cases.\nOf course, the author sincerely hopes that cyber-operations will never result in fatalities or large-scale physical destruction. Yet, to try to increase potential deterrence of such harmful events, it is important to make clear that the ICC could prosecute certain cyber-operations meeting the legal requirements of the Rome Statute, including gravity. Communicating this by the ICC, and/or pursuing cases that fall within that limited subset, could be important in conveying that states may not achieve through cyber means what would be Rome Statute crimes if committed through kinetic/conventional means — a risk that increases as technology continues to develop.\n While developed states parties should be ‘willing’ and ‘able’ to use their courts to prosecute cyber-operations, which would render an ICC case ‘inadmissible’, it will depend if the domestic laws of the particular state: (1) encompass the particular conduct at issue, and (2) reach the conduct to the extent it occurred abroad — with perpetrators and victims potentially in many countries. Thus, the totality of the crime might not be ‘able’ to be prosecuted within the domestic courts of any one state party, potentially rendering the case ‘admissible’ before the ICC. States parties that have implemented Rome Statute crimes into their domestic criminal codes thereby have at least certain cyber-operations criminalized, but not all states parties have enacted implementing legislation.\n As mentioned above, arguably, none of the cyber-operations to date has yet reached the threshold that is probably required by the Rome Statute — with the possible exception of those in Ukraine and the potentially cyber-enabled genocides in Myanmar and against the Uighurs. But see supra note 75 (concerning the jurisdictional principle in the Bangladesh/Myanmar Decision).\n Because there hopefully will be few, if any, cyber-operations rising to the level of Rome Statute gravity and satisfying the elements of the crimes, the ICC’s docket should not be significantly impacted.",

  "sections": {
    "# 1. Introduction": "This article examines how a cyber-operation (an activity enabled by conduct in cyberspace) that has consequences similar to a kinetic or physical attack (causing serious loss of life or physical damage) could be encompassed within the crimes that may be prosecuted by the International Criminal Court (ICC).¹ While this article is a conversation starter and does not contain a comprehensive discussion of all the elements of the crimes, or all potential cyber-operations that might fit within their ambit, it provides an overview of when and how a cyber-operation could constitute genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, or the crime of aggression. It includes the potential for prosecuting both state actors (e.g. those within cyber-command structures, armed forces, or intelligence agencies) and non-state actors (cyber-criminals or informal bands of hackers).² Additionally, the article acknowledges some of the limitations on the prosecution of cyber-operations, such as the Rome Statute’s gravity threshold as well as the potential difficulty of attributing conduct to a particular suspect through admissible evidence that could, at trial, met the threshold of proof beyond reasonable doubt. Notwithstanding these limitations, increased awareness of the potential of the Rome Statute to encompass certain cyber-operations could contribute to deterring the commission of crimes by these means, as would actual prosecution(s) by the ICC, were the necessary requirements met.\nRecognition that cyber-operations can, in certain circumstances, constitute Rome Statute crimes could additionally help align the ICC’s work with one of the newer challenges facing the international community in the 21st century — thereby re-affirming the relevance of the Court in a way that may not have been previously envisioned. For states that have implemented Rome Statute crimes into their domestic criminal laws, the potential for additional deterrence could be created through the use of such laws — recognizing that such legislation could be broader in scope, as it would not need to be bound to the ICC’s definitions of crimes nor by its jurisdictional limitations. While the Rome Statute admittedly would not encompass the vast number of cyber-crimes\n¹ ‘Cyber-operation’ is a broad term indicating the employment of cyber-capabilities aimed at achieving its objectives in and through cyber-space. This article focuses on a narrow subset of cyber-operations that are harmful or malicious, particularly ones that could involve large-scale loss of life, or damage to, or destruction of, property. The term ‘cyber-attack’ might also be used, although the author does not do so here, as that term risks conflation with an ‘attack’ under International Humanitarian Law (IHL) or an ‘armed attack’ under *jus ad bellum*.\n² The expert report by the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare is a welcome addition in exploring these significant topics. See *The Council of Advisers’ Report on The Application of The Rome Statute of The International Criminal Court to Cyberwarfare*, prepared by the Permanent Mission of Liechtenstein to the United Nations (2021). Expert meetings of the Council of Advisers were hosted by the Permanent Mission of the Principality of Liechtenstein to the United Nations, and co-organized by the Permanent Missions of Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Costa Rica, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Spain, and Switzerland, as well as the Global Institute for the Prevention of Aggression. The author as well as other members of the Council of Advisers contributed to the writing of the expert report, with the bulk of the writing supervised by Liechtenstein legal adviser Sina Alavi.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1135\nthat are occurring (such as data theft or extortion) — as it would only cover a limited subset of cyber-operations such as those inflicting serious loss of life or significant physical damage — the Rome Statute does have potential for use in this area. An added benefit is that such prosecutions may occur without any amendment to the Rome Statute, as at least this limited subset of cyber-operations is covered under its existing provisions.",
    "## 2. Background": "The past decade or two has witnessed a significantly large number of cyber-operations in a variety of forms, including those aimed at data-theft (stealing corporate information), extortion, spreading of false information, manipulation of elections, breach of government computers in an effort to steal state secrets, as well as 'denial of service' attacks. Cyber-operations can be harmful by their nature (e.g. employing some form of malware) or because of their content (e.g. disinformation or misinformation campaigns or hate speech). Cyber-operations have sometimes proliferated beyond their originally intended targets to impacting information technology (IT) systems around the globe.³ To date, fortunately, cyber-operations have not resulted in widespread devastation that has caused loss of life, and, to the extent physical damage has resulted, it has been mostly to data, computer hardware and software, or, in one instance, centrifuges at a nuclear facility (the Stuxnet attack).⁴ Cyber-operations have also caused massive economic loss⁵ and compromised the personal information of millions of individuals.⁶\nThe use of cyber-technology to date, however, makes clear that a much more catastrophic cyber-operation could occur. States are increasingly developing and utilizing cyber-weaponry as a means of warfare, and may combine cyber-weapons with conventional weapons in a 'blended attack'.⁷ Many of the\n3 This occurred with the infamous NotPetya attack. See A. Greenberg, 'The Untold Story of NotPetya, the Most Devastating Cyberattack in History', Wired (22 August 2018), available online at https://www.wired.com/story/notpetya-cyberattack-ukraine-russia-code-crashed-the-world/ (visited 30 January 2021). For additional discussion of the Petya/NotPetya attack, see D. Efrony and Y. Shany, 'A Rule Book on the Shelf? Tallinn Manual 2.0 on Cyberoperations and Subsequent State Practice', 112 American Journal of International Law (2018) 583, at 628–631.\n4 The 'Stuxnet' attack targeted nuclear facilities in Natanz. Most experts believe it to have been perpetrated by the US and Israel. E. Nakashima and J. Warrick, 'Stuxnet Was Work of U.S. and Israeli Experts, Officials Say', Washington Post (2 June 2012), available online at https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/stuxnet-was-work-of-us-and-israeli-experts-officials-say/2012/06/01/gJQAlnEy6U_story.html (visited 30 January 2021).\n5 See Greenberg, supra note 3 (estimating nine-figure costs in multiple situations).\n6 E.T. Jensen, 'The Tallinn Manual 2.0: Highlights and Insights', 48 Georgetown Journal of International Law (2017) 735, at 737 ('the significance of cyber hacking has become a reality for millions of individuals whose personal information has been compromised through cyber means').\n7 Such a 'blended attack' occurred in Ukraine, where both physical/kinetic military operations as well as cyber-operation by the [Russian-affiliated] hacker team known as 'Sandworm' (also known as 'Voodoo Bear' and 'Telebots') hacked into dozens of Ukrainian governmental\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nwar crimes that could be committed during a conventional armed conflict could potentially also be committed through cyber means, or by employing both cyber and conventional weapons. Outside a state of armed conflict, cyber-operations meeting the requirements of, inter alia, a widespread or systematic attack on a civilian population could fall within the ambit of ‘crimes against humanity’. Here, one need only to realize that by disabling air-traffic controls, the capability exists to cause a ‘cyber 9/11’, perpetrated, for example, by non-state actors (cyber-criminals or bands of hackers). A cyber-operation could similarly target computer systems that control critical or safety-critical infrastructure such as train traffic, nuclear facilities,⁸ hospitals,⁹ power grids,¹⁰ or a dam located upstream from a major city.¹¹ One can imagine a long list of such targets that could be manipulated by a cyber-operation to cause serious loss of life and/or physical destruction. It is this limited subset of cyber-operations, carrying potentially grave consequences — rather than the vast number of cyber-crimes being perpetrated for pure financial gain — that this article addresses.¹²\norganizations and companies. See Greenberg, supra note 3. The 2008 attack on Georgia was also ‘blended’. See ICC Forum, ‘New Frontiers for the ICC (International Criminal Court): Tackling Cyber Attacks through the Crime of Aggression’ (22 February 2018), available online at https://iccforum.com/forum/permalink/110/13832 (visited 30 January 2021).\n8 See e.g. A. Greenberg, ‘Hack Brief: Hackers Targeted a US Nuclear Plant (But Don’t Panic Yet)’, Wired (6 July 2017), available online at https://www.wired.com/story/hack-brief-us-nuclear-power-breach/#intcid=recommendations_wired-bottom-recirc-similar_1691318a-b422-4428-96db-e7512a834566_text2vec1_text2VecSimilarity (visited 30 January 2021). See also note 4 supra (Stuxnet).\n9 See e.g. A. Glaser, ‘U.S. Hospitals Have Been Hit by the Global Ransomware Attack’, Vox (27 June 2017), available online at https://www.vox.com/2017/6/27/15881666/global-eu-cyber-attack-us-hackers-nsa-hospitals (visited 30 January 2021) (part of NotPetya); K. Mačák, L. Gisel, and T. Rodenhäuser, ‘Cyber Attacks against Hospitals and COVID-19 Pandemic: How Strong Are International Law Protections?’, Just Security (27 March 2020), available online at https://www.justsecurity.org/69407/cyber-attacks-against-hospitals-and-the-covid-19-pandemic-how-strong-are-international-law-protections/ (visited 30 January 2021). See also text accompanying note 116 infra (hospitals in Ukraine).\n10 See e.g. A. Greenberg, ‘Hackers Gain Direct Access to US Power Grid Controls’, Wired (6 September 2017), available online at https://www.wired.com/story/hackers-gain-switch-flipping-access-to-us-power-systems/#intcid=recommendations_wired-bottom-recirc-similar_712531e1-69ed-4994-b83b-891af026859f_text2vec1_text2VecSimilarity (visited 30 January 2021). See also Greenberg, supra note 3 (widespread power outages in Ukraine).\n11 A small dam located fewer than 15 miles north of New York City was penetrated in 2016 by Iranian cyber-operations. J. Berger, ‘A Dam, Small and Unsung, Is Caught Up in an Iranian Hacking Case’, New York Times (26 March 2016), available online at https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/26/nyregion/rye-brook-dam-caught-in-computer-hacking-case.html (visited 30 January 2021).\n12 See O.A. Hathaway et al., ‘The Law of Cyber Attack’, California Law Review (2012) 817, at 834 (differentiating cyber-attacks from cyber-crime). See also supra note 1. Arguably, none of the cyber-operations to date has yet reached the threshold that is probably required by the Rome Statute, with the possible exception of those in Ukraine. See infra notes 116–121 and accompanying text (discussing cyber-attacks in Ukraine). Potentially, the genocide in Myanmar was cyber-enabled: see infra note 150. However, the ICC lacks jurisdiction over crimes committed solely within Myanmar. See infra note 75 and accompanying text. The genocide against the\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1137\nIdeally, state actors will develop cyber-technology, including cyber-weapons, in a responsible way, with a view to adhering to the laws of war when such weapons are utilized, such that cyber-operations — which can be precisely targeted¹³ — are directed only at military objectives and never civilian populations nor civilian or other protected objects, nor used indiscriminately or in a way that results in disproportionate ‘collateral damage’. Yet, unfortunately, not all states are committed to adhering to the laws of war and this most likely is and will be true also in the cyber-domain. (Indeed, the temptation to ignore international law could be even greater in the cyber-domain, where it is sometimes additionally difficult to identify who has launched a cyber-operation.¹⁴) Furthermore, even states generally committed to complying with the laws of war rarely achieve complete compliance, as law appears particularly susceptible to violation during a state of armed conflict. Cyber-operations can also inadvertently proliferate beyond their intended target¹⁵ and the software code used in cyber-operations may be ‘repurposed’ by others.¹⁶ Concerns multiply when one considers the possibility of cyber-operations being perpetrated by (or of software used in cyber operations repurposed by) non-state actors (e.g. cyber-criminals/transnational criminal groups, terrorist organizations, loosely affiliated bands of hackers, or even isolated individuals). Such non-state actors could also be operating at the instigation or behest of a state.¹⁷ Cyberwarfare may in some ways ‘level the playing field’ insofar as not only powerful militaries can launch potentially destructive cyber-operations, but this is a double-edged sword. A cyber-operation could in theory be launched from one lone computer or a network of computers, making even lone hackers potentially powerful adversaries.¹⁸\nUighurs may also be cyber-enabled, see infra note 149, but the ICC also lacks jurisdiction over crimes committed in China, a non-state party.\n¹³ See e.g. S.M. Bellovin, S. Landau, and H.S. Lin, ‘Limiting the Undesired Impact of Cyber Weapons: Technical Requirements and Policy Implications’, 3 Journal of Cybersecurity (2017) 59; N.C. Rowe, ‘War Crimes from Cyberweapons’, 6 Journal of Information Warfare (2007) 15, available online at https://faculty.nps.edu/ncrowe/iwcrimes.htm (visited 30 January 2021) (‘Cyber-attacks can and should be designed to be selective in what systems they attack and what they attack in those systems’).\n¹⁴ See infra Section 3.B. (difficulties of attribution).\n¹⁵ This occurred with the NotPetya attack.\n¹⁶ States can design cyber-weapons to reduce proliferation risks and to reduce the ability of others to ‘repurpose’ cyber-weapons: Bellovin et al., supra note 13, at 60.\n¹⁷ See e.g. J. Taylor, ‘Chinese Cyberhackers “Blurring Line Between State Power and Crime”’, The Guardian (7 August 2019), available online at https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/aug/08/chinese-cyberhackers-blurring-line-between-state-power-and (visited 30 January 2021) (discussing a group of state-sponsored hackers in China).\n¹⁸ See K. Mačák, ‘On the Shelf, But Close At Hand: The Contribution of Non-State Initiatives to International Cyber Law’, AJIL Unbound (2019) 81, at 82 (‘Asymmetries of cyberspace mean that the most powerful nations are, in a peculiar way, also the most vulnerable ones’); Hathaway et al., supra note 12, at 842 (‘Because it is much less costly to mount cyber-attacks than to launch conventional attacks, and because highly industrialized states are generally more dependent upon computer networks and are more vulnerable to cyber-attacks, cyber-attacks may prove to be a powerful weapon of the weak’).\n1138\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nThis article suggests that each of the crimes in the ICC's Rome Statute — war crimes, crimes again humanity, genocide, and the crime of aggression — can be applied at least to a limited subset of cyber-operations. While a full explanation of every element of every crime is beyond the scope of this article, the author will set forth some initial observations on the characteristics of cyber-operations which might amount to Rome Statute crimes, while acknowledging some limiting factors. Specifically, Part 3 below considers five initial overarching considerations relevant to all Rome Statute crimes: (1) which cyber-operations might meet the Rome Statute's 'gravity' threshold; (2) the need to prove attribution through admissible evidence that could satisfy the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt; (3) questions of jurisdiction; (4) the Rome Statute's 'intent' requirement; and (5) the prohibition on expanding the definition of crimes by analogy. Part 4 then provides an overview of how certain cyber-operations could fall within the Rome Statute's substantive crimes.¹⁹",
    "## 3. Overarching Considerations": "### A. Which Cyber-operations Would Satisfy the ICC's Gravity Threshold?\nAn initial key area for consideration is what kinds of cyber-operations could satisfy the gravity threshold of the Rome Statute. In order to be 'admissible', Article 17 of the Rome Statute requires that a case must be of 'sufficient gravity to justify ... action by the Court'.²⁰ Additionally, Article 53 states that the Prosecutor may only initiate an investigation or proceed with a case if that case 'would be admissible under Article 17'.²¹\nA recent Appeals Chamber decision explains the gravity requirement:\n[T]he gravity requirement ... aims at excluding those rather unusual cases where the specific facts of a given case technically qualify as crimes under the jurisdiction of the Court, but are nonetheless not of sufficient gravity to justify further action by the Court. ... '[T]he purpose of article 17(1)(d) of the Statute is not to oblige the Court to choose only the most serious cases, but merely to oblige it not to prosecute cases of marginal gravity'. ...\n[T]he Pre-Trial Chamber ... held that when determining whether the gravity requirement ... is fulfilled, both quantitative and qualitative criteria are relevant considerations. It\n¹⁹ This article does not analyze issues related to individual criminal responsibility or superior responsibility. For a discussion of superior responsibility for cyber-attacks, see E. van Sliedregt, 'Command Responsibility and Cyberattacks', 21 Journal of Conflict &amp; Security Law (2016) 505.\n²⁰ Art. 17(1)(d) ICCSt.\n²¹ Art. 53(1)(b) ICCSt.; see also Art. 53(2)(b) ICCSt. There are actually two gravity assessments: (1) gravity in evaluating the 'admissibility' of a situation, and (2) gravity in case selection. See OTP Policy Paper on Case Selection and Prioritization (15 September 2016), available online at https://www.icc-cpi.int/itemsDocuments/20160915_OTP-Policy_Case-Selection_Eng.pdf (visited 30 January 2021), §§ 32 (gravity as a criterion for admissibility), 35–41 (gravity for case selection).\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1139\nfurther noted that some factors ... could provide relevant guidance to the assessment of gravity ... including the extent of the damage caused, the nature of the unlawful behaviour, the means employed to execute the crime, the degree of participation of the accused person, the degree of intent, the circumstances of manner, time and location, the existence of particularly defenceless victims, the commission of crimes with particular cruelty or where there are multiple victims, and the commission of crimes for any motive involving discrimination. ... [T]he Appeals Chamber agrees with this approach.²²\nGiven the multitude of cyber-crimes that would not reach the Rome Statute's gravity threshold, and the significant number of cyber-operations that also might not do so, it becomes important to analyse which cyber-operations could reach that threshold. A useful starting point is found in the work of a group of independent experts who, convened at the invitation of the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence based in Tallinn, Estonia, produced two manuals. The first, referred to as 'Tallinn 1.0', addresses international law applicable to cyber-warfare.²³ The second, convened by a more diverse group of experts and referred to as 'Tallinn 2.0',²⁴ addresses cyber-operations more broadly, both during and outside armed conflict.²⁵ The Tallinn Manuals are extremely important in making clear that international law (including IHL, international human rights law, and jus ad bellum) applies in the area of cyber-operations. Although the Manuals are not binding law on the ICC (nor elsewhere), and states and experts hold divergent views on the weight to accord to them,²⁷ at minimum, they provide a useful starting point for analysis.²⁸\nWhile the Tallinn experts opined on international law more broadly (addressing neither the ICC nor its gravity threshold), one topic they discussed was when a cyber-operation would qualify as a ‘use of force’. (That language is of course significant in analysing when Article 2(4) of the UN Charter is violated.²⁹) Specifically, they opined that a cyber-operation constitutes a ‘use of force’ when it has ‘scale and effects’ similar to a physical/kinetic attack.³⁰ Thus, the Tallinn Manual 2.0 takes the position that ‘acts that injure or kill persons or physically damage or destroy objects’ would amount to ‘uses of force’.³¹ The experts additionally suggested various criteria that ‘States are likely to consider’ as to when a cyber-operation constitutes a ‘use of force’, including: severity, immediacy, directness, invasiveness, and measurability of effects.³² While admittedly formulated for a different purpose, this definition is nonetheless helpful for considering which cyber-operations might reach the ICC’s gravity threshold and these criteria appear useful ones for the ICC Prosecutor to consider in making the assessment. Specifically, the Tallinn experts relied on the ruling of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Nicaragua case that an ‘armed attack’ is a ‘particularly serious’ form of the ‘use of force’.³⁹ They concluded that ‘a cyber operation that seriously injures or kills a number of persons or that causes significant damage to, or destruction of, property would satisfy the scale and effects requirement’ and thus constitute an ‘armed attack’.⁴⁰ This provides a definition that might better approximate what the ICC’s gravity threshold should be when considering cyber-operations.⁴¹\nAt the same time, it is useful to consider whether one should fully close the door to cyber-operations that do not satisfy the Tallinn Manual’s definitions (of either ‘use of force’ or ‘armed attack’) from reaching the Rome Statute’s gravity threshold.⁴² For instance, France has suggested that operations that penetrate military systems to weaken French defensive capabilities, even if this does not produce physical effects, would constitute a ‘use of force’.⁴³ While France is not taking the view that such conduct would constitute a Rome Statute crime, it is worth considering whether it would reach Rome Statute gravity (assuming the elements of a Rome Statute crime could be demonstrated). The Tallinn Manual has been heavily criticized for omitting denial of service (DDoS) attacks and destruction of data under the purview of 'use of force'; yet, even if they were considered 'use of force', that still would not answer the question whether they should rise to the level of Rome Statute gravity. What about deaths that only remotely ensue but are connected by the chain of causation? What about causing a global shipping conglomerate and a number of other companies around the world to lose or need to shut down all IT functions in a massive malware attack that causes extensive economic loss? What if this happened in conjunction with the destruction of terabytes of data of governmental organizations and companies, from media outlets to railway firms, followed by widespread power outages?\nThese questions will require far more extensive consideration. The ICC's cases, to date, have focused on more 'traditional' areas. Possibly, in the future, the OTP might want to consider issuing a policy paper on gravity and cyber-operations, or on cyber-operations and the Rome Statute. For present purposes, the author will suggest that it may be a helpful start to adopt the Tallinn Manual's definition of an 'armed attack' as a starting point for when a cyber-operation could satisfy the Rome Statute's gravity threshold. That is, a cyber-operation that causes serious injuries or loss of life and/or significant physical damage or destruction is one that could satisfy the Rome Statute's gravity threshold. Another area that will require further consideration is whether destruction of data should be included. For example, Matthew Cross writes:\nIncreasing attention is generally being paid to the ‘expressivist’ function of international criminal law, which places emphasis on the significance of criminal prosecution and punishment as symbolising the legal and moral condemnation of the constituents of international criminal law (the international community, victims, etc). Alternatively, a cyber-operation (or a physical/kinetic attack) by itself may not necessarily trigger a state of ‘armed conflict’, so then one would not meet the contextual requirement for war crimes at all. Similarly, while a limited number of fatalities, or even no fatalities, could theoretically constitute the crime of genocide if the special mental state requirement of genocide (dolus specialis) were established,⁵⁷ in the situations of genocide that have been prosecuted to date before international criminal tribunals the number of fatalities has been considerable;⁵⁸ thus, charging genocide absent significant fatalities could prove a risky prosecutorial strategy. As to crimes against humanity, if a single target is involved, with a limited number of victims, one may not have an attack that is ‘widespread’ or ‘systematic.’ Furthermore, as to the crime of aggression, the jurisdictional limitations appear to be so restrictive⁵⁹ that it may be difficult to satisfy jurisdiction (absent Security Council referral)⁶⁰ even if the ‘gravity’ threshold were met.\n## B. Proving Attribution through Admissible Evidence that Establishes Proof Beyond a Reasonable Doubt\nAn additional limiting factor (relevant for all ICC crimes) would be that all the elements of the crime would need to be proven through admissible evidence that could eventually satisfy the requirement at trial of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.⁶¹ Lower standards apply at the ICC for opening an investigation,⁶² issuing a warrant,⁶³ and for confirmation of charges⁶⁴ — but those standards would not apply at trial, where ultimately proof is required beyond a\n⁵⁷ See Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, 9 December 1948, 78 UNTS 277, Art. This includes the issue of attribution (who conducted the cyber-operation), tracking it back not just to a state (or non-state actor/hacker group working for the state), but potentially to a particular ‘computer … to identify the person who operated the computer, and more importantly to identify the real mastermind’ behind the attack.\nAttribution may be a challenge for all crimes, but particularly so for conduct in cyberspace. Not only do cyber-attackers sometimes go to considerable lengths to conceal cyber-operations, states have at times deliberately hidden their cyber-operations as perpetrated by another state ('false-flagging'). This, for example, happened when 'Russian hackers piggy-backed on an Iranian cyber-espionage operation', thereby reportedly hacking into 'government and industry organizations in dozens of countries while masquerading as attackers from the Islamic Republic [of Iran]. Or states can hide behind non-state actors to mask their operations. Even when that is not the case, cyber-operations can be difficult to attribute because they can be perpetrated through a single computer or network of computers located far from where the consequences impact, and also can be concealed by feigning that operating systems are functioning normally. Furthermore, if attribution is to be made, this raises questions as to who would be in a position to do so. Will it be practical for the ICC to do this by itself? And, if not, what are the implications of relying on state cooperation in this regard?\nFor Rome Statute purposes, proof of attribution would need to be demonstrated through admissible evidence and this will require authentication; moreover, simply assembling a cyber-case would be extremely complex. The OTP would need to develop significant technical expertise as would, eventually, Chambers, Defense counsel, and other participants in the ICC judicial process. This knowledge could be internally developed through hiring and/or the use of outside experts; yet, all of this might be very difficult to organize without excellent state cooperation. The more that cyber investigatory capacities of the ICC increase, the more important will it be for the court to have in place protections safeguarding privacy and related digital rights; the ICC will thus need (and probably should already have) a privacy policy and data protection standards that are binding on the institution.72\n## C. Issues of Jurisdiction\nWhile questions of jurisdiction merit a far more extensive analysis, it is worth initially observing that a cyber-operation may often be launched from one state (the 'attacker' state), where the operations originated, with consequences (or 'effects')73 felt in one or more (even many) 'victim' states. Absent a Security Council referral, either the 'attacker' state or 'victim' state would need to be a state party to the Rome Statute, or the perpetrators would need to be nationals of a state party — because the Rome Statute gives the ICC jurisdiction over the nationals of, and crimes committed on the territory of, states parties.74 In this latter regard, the Pre-Trial Chamber's ruling in the Myanmar/Bangladesh situation holds that at least one element of the crime must have been committed on the territory of a state party for ICC jurisdiction to exist.75\nWhere many states are impacted, the question arises whether even a modest amount of impact (effects) in one ICC state party would suffice to give the ICC jurisdiction, or whether some kind of threshold must be satisfied — and, if so, whether this threshold may be satisfied collectively if multiple states are affected, and whether they would all have to be ICC states parties? For example, if the attack produces consequences in ten states but only one is an ICC state party, would that suffice to create jurisdiction if the effects in the one state party do not independently satisfy the threshold but the effects in the ten states would do so? The preliminary answer from the ICC appears to be in the affirmative. In the Comoros situation, the Pre-Trial Chamber confirmed its view\n72 See A. Lubin, 'Politics, Power Dynamics, and the Limits of Existing Self-Regulation and Oversight in ICC Preliminary Examinations' (making this suggestion), in M. Bergsmo and C. Stahn (eds), Quality Control in Preliminary Examination: Vol. 2 (Torkel Opsahl Academic EPublisher, 2018) 78, 141–143.\n73 There is an entire body of jurisdiction based on the 'effects' test. See e.g. The S.S. 'Lotus' (France v. Turkey), P.C.I.J. Ser. A, No. 10, p. 4 (1927). However, for the ICC's purposes, the more salient inquiry appears to be whether one element of the crime occurred on the territory of a state party (objective territoriality). The ‘Intent’ Requirement and Unintended Consequences\nGiven that several cyber-operations to date have proliferated well-beyond their intended targets,⁸⁶ another question is whether the Rome Statute would have any applicability for unintended results; here, one might consider both (1) unintended and foreseeable consequences, and (2) unintended and unforeseeable consequences. These issues were considered by the Tallinn experts in terms of responsibility more generally (not in the Rome Statute context).⁸⁷ The Rome Statute appears to take a fairly restrictive approach with its requirements of ‘intent’ and ‘knowledge’ in Article 30. Article 30(2) specifies that ‘intent’ exists when (1) a ‘person means to engage in the conduct’ or (2) ‘is aware that [the consequences] will occur in the ordinary course of events’.⁸⁸ ‘Knowledge’ is defined as awareness that a ‘circumstance exists’ or ‘a consequence will occur in the ordinary course of events’.⁸⁹ While there is some support for including notions such as conscious risk-taking or recklessness, the ‘leading view in the early practice of the ICC’ takes a ‘restrictive interpretation’.⁹⁰ Thus, ‘[t]he Lubanga appeal judgment confirmed the interpretation put forward in the Bemba decision on the confirmation of charges, that under Article 30 … “the standard for the foreseeability of events is virtual certainty”’.⁹¹\n⁸⁴ United Nations Treaty Collection, Ch. XVIII, Penal Matters, ‘Amendments on the Crime of Aggression to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court’, as of 18 January 2021, available online at https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XVIII-10-b&amp;chapter=18⟨=en (visited 30 January 2021).\n⁸⁵ See Arts 13(b), 15ter ICCSt. For background on Security Council referrals and the crime of aggression, see J. Trahan, ‘Revisiting the Role of the Security Council Regarding the International Criminal Court’s Crime of Aggression’, 17 Journal of International Criminal Justice (2019) 471.\n⁸⁶ See supra note 7 (Ukraine).\n⁸⁷ See Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 343, §§ 13–14 (considering reasonably foreseeable consequences versus unexpected results).\n⁸⁸ Art. 30(2)(a)-(b) ICCSt.\n⁸⁹ Art. 30(3) ICCSt.\n⁹⁰ Case Matrix Network, Art. 30(2)(b), Intent in Relation to Result (Mohamed Elewa Badar and Sara Porro, authors) updated 18 August 2017.\n⁹¹ Ibid. (citing Judgment on the Appeal of Mr. Thomas Lubanga Dyilo Against His Conviction, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-A-5), Appeals Chamber, 1 December 2014, § 441 et seq; Decision Pursuant to Article 61(7)(a) and (b) of the Rome Statute on the Charges of the Prosecutor Against Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo, Bemba (ICC-01/05-01/08-424), Pre-Trial Chamber, 15 June 2009, § 359 et seq). Other cases also endorse this ‘virtual certainty’ standard: see Judgment, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-3121-Red A5), Appeals Chamber, 1 December 2014, § 447; Judgment Pursuant to Article 74 of the Statute, Katanga (ICC-01/04-01/07-3436), Trial Chamber II, 7 March 2014, §§ 776–777.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1151\nIf ICC jurisprudence remains consistent with that approach, responsibility would not attach to unforeseeable consequences, and even as to foreseeable consequences, the threshold would be quite high — ‘virtual certainty’ that the consequences will result. For example, imagine a dam above a city is penetrated and water released flooding a city below the dam. Under the Lubanga/Bemba standard, responsibility would only attach for flooding the city if there were ‘virtual certainty’ of that consequence. (By contrast, the ad hoc tribunals found there was responsibility for ‘reasonably foreseeable’ crimes when applying ‘joint criminal enterprise’ (type 3).⁹²) While a strong argument can be made that recklessness should sometimes rise to the level of intent (and some older ICC Pre-Trial decisions take that approach),⁹³ it does not seem to be the ICC’s primary approach, nor does the ICC appear to adopt the standard of ‘reasonable foreseeability’.⁹⁴ ‘Intentional endangerment’ arguably should, however, create individual criminal responsibility and the ICC’s states parties might consider a Rome Statute amendment to expressly encompass it as satisfying the intent requirement. Note also that domestic courts, as mentioned, as well as other international or hybrid tribunals are not limited by the Rome Statute’s standards — so the Rome Statute’s failure to encompass ‘recklessness’ does not mean that it is displaced in international criminal law more generally. Thus, the requirements in Article 30 of ‘intent’ and ‘knowledge’ could prove an additional limiting factor, excluding criminal responsibility for unforeseeable results and setting a high standard as to foreseeable results, requiring ‘virtual certainty’ of the consequences.⁹⁵\n## E. Arguing about the similarities between a physical/kinetic attack and a cyber-operation, for example, may not suffice, because it would be suggesting application by analogy. This limitation and the presumption that ambiguity favours the defendant, however, does not mean that one could not give an updated, modern reading to Rome Statute provisions. Law, to serve a useful purpose, should meet contemporary challenges.⁹⁷ Furthermore, the Rome Statute is generally 'weapons neutral' or 'technology neutral' — one applies the crimes regardless of the particular weapon or technology utilized; viewed in this light, cyber is simply akin to a new weapon or technology system.\nThus, the above discussion suggests the potentially applicability of the Rome Statute to a limited subset of cyber-operations (1) if they meet the Rome Statute's gravity threshold; (2) where attribution could be proven, eventually, beyond a reasonable doubt; (3) where jurisdiction exists; (4) where 'intent' can be demonstrated (which appears to exclude responsibility for unforeseen consequences and limit responsibility even for foreseen consequences); and (5) where the harm caused falls within the definition of a Rome Statute crime without drawing upon analogies, with ambiguity construed to favour the defence.",

Conclusion": "This article has only touched the surface of what will need to be a far more extensive study of how the crimes in the ICC’s Rome Statute could potentially encompass cyber-operations. Much has been written by cyber experts on the application of the laws of war to cyber operations and on how IHL violations can create war crimes exposure; that body of writing alone clearly suggests the Rome Statute’s potential applicability. As mentioned, an expert report by the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare¹⁷⁴ will contribute further to exploring these important topics.\nWhile the ICC’s cases to date have primarily concerned atrocity crimes committed in less economically developed areas, a role for the Court in addressing even a limited subset of cyber-operations might help to reinforce\nthe crime of aggression, which provides there is no jurisdiction regarding the nationals of non-states parties. See Art. 15bis(5), ICCSt.\n¹⁷¹ See e.g. S.J. Schakelford, ‘The Law of Cyber Peace’, 18 Chicago Journal of International Law (2017) 11 (quoting the Nicaragua case, supra note 39 (as a matter of sovereignty, nations have an obligation not to interfere in one another’s domestic affairs if that intervention relates to ‘the choice of a political, economic, social, and cultural system’); Efrony and Shany, supra note 3, at 640 (discussing how cyber-operations can violate sovereignty); Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 17 (‘Rule 4: A State must not conduct cyber operations that violate the sovereignty of another State’).\n¹⁷² See Efrony and Shany, supra note 3, at 609–617 (discussing cyber election interference by the Russian Federation).\n¹⁷³ Art. 15bis(5) ICCSt.\n¹⁷⁴ See supra note 2.\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nits relevance for states with developed economies¹⁷⁵ — all of which (along with states with developing economies) are experiencing an enormous number of cyber-attacks.¹⁷⁶ Accordingly, various states parties to the Rome Statute may welcome the recognition that certain cyber-operations could constitute Rome Statute crimes, and support the ICC’s addressing of such cases.\nOf course, the author sincerely hopes that cyber-operations will never result in fatalities or large-scale physical destruction. Yet, to try to increase potential deterrence of such harmful events, it is important to make clear that the ICC could prosecute certain cyber-operations meeting the legal requirements of the Rome Statute, including gravity. Communicating this by the ICC, and/or pursuing cases that fall within that limited subset,¹⁷⁷ could be important in conveying that states may not achieve through cyber means what would be Rome Statute crimes if committed through kinetic/conventional means — a risk that increases as technology continues to develop.\n¹⁷⁵ While developed states parties should be ‘willing’ and ‘able’ to use their courts to prosecute cyber-operations, which would render an ICC case ‘inadmissible’, it will depend if the domestic laws of the particular state: (1) encompass the particular conduct at issue, and (2) reach the conduct to the extent it occurred abroad — with perpetrators and victims potentially in many countries. Thus, the totality of the crime might not be ‘able’ to be prosecuted within the domestic courts of any one state party, potentially rendering the case ‘admissible’ before the ICC. States parties that have implemented Rome Statute crimes into their domestic criminal codes thereby have at least certain cyber-operations criminalized, but not all states parties have enacted implementing legislation.\n¹⁷⁶ As mentioned above, arguably, none of the cyber-operations to date has yet reached the threshold that is probably required by the Rome Statute — with the possible exception of those in Ukraine and the potentially cyber-enabled genocides in Myanmar and against the Uighurs. But see supra note 75 (concerning the jurisdictional principle in the Bangladesh/Myanmar Decision).\n¹⁷⁷ Because there hopefully will be few, if any, cyber-operations rising to the level of Rome Statute gravity and satisfying the elements of the crimes, the ICC’s docket should not be significantly impacted."

    "flat_text": "SYMPOSIUM\nAPPLICATION OF ICL TO INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES, IN PARTICULAR TO CYBER-OPERATIONS\n# The Criminalization of Cyber-operations Under the Rome Statute\nJennifer Trahan*\n# Abstract\nThis article examines how a cyber-operation that has consequences similar to a kinetic or physical attack — causing serious loss of life or physical damage — could be encompassed within the crimes prosecuted before the International Criminal Court (ICC). It explains when and how such a cyber-operation could fall within the ambit of the ICC's crimes — genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression. The article additionally acknowledges some limitations as to which cyber-operations would be encompassed, given the ICC's gravity threshold as well as the potential difficulty of attributing conduct to a particular suspect through admissible evidence that could meet the requirement of proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Notwithstanding such limitations, increased awareness of the previously largely overlooked potential of the Rome Statute to cover certain cyber-operations could potentially contribute to deterring such crimes.\n* Clinical Professor, NYU Center for Global Affairs, USA. The author greatly benefitted from attending meetings of the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare, convened by the Permanent Mission of Liechtenstein to the United Nations, on which she was privileged to serve. See note 2. She also thanks Pano Yannakogeorgos for aiding her understanding of cyber-operations. The author appreciates being able to discuss the article at workshops sponsored by the Ostrom Workshop Program on Cybersecurity and Internet Governance at Indiana University, and at the 2020 International Criminal Court Scholars' Forum. She particularly appreciates the comments of her respective discussants Asaf Lubin and Elies van Sliedregt, as well as the comments and edits of Matthew Cross. Erin Lovall, Kara McDonald, and Samantha Wynne provided research assistance. A shorter version of this article, more focused on deterrence, will appear in S. Shackleford, F. Douzet, and C. Ankersen (eds), Cyber Peace: Charting a Path Toward a Sustainable, Stable, and Secure CyberSpace (forthcoming, Cambridge University Press, 2022). [jt487@nyu.edu]\nJournal of International Criminal Justice 19 (2021), 1133–1164\n© The Author(s) (2021). Published by Oxford University Press.
