Introduction\nThis article examines how a cyber-operation (an activity enabled by conduct in cyberspace) that has consequences similar to a kinetic or physical attack (causing serious loss of life or physical damage) could be encompassed within the crimes that may be prosecuted by the International Criminal Court (ICC). While this article is a conversation starter and does not contain a comprehensive discussion of all the elements of the crimes, or all potential cyber-operations that might fit within their ambit, it provides an overview of when and how a cyber-operation could constitute genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, or the crime of aggression. It includes the potential for prosecuting both state actors (e.g. those within cyber-command structures, armed forces, or intelligence agencies) and non-state actors (cyber-criminals or informal bands of hackers). Additionally, the article acknowledges some of the limitations on the prosecution of cyber-operations, such as the Rome Statute’s gravity threshold as well as the potential difficulty of attributing conduct to a particular suspect through admissible evidence that could, at trial, met the threshold of proof beyond reasonable doubt. Notwithstanding these limitations, increased awareness of the potential of the Rome Statute to encompass certain cyber-operations could contribute to deterring the commission of crimes by these means, as would actual prosecution(s) by the ICC, were the necessary requirements met.\nRecognition that cyber-operations can, in certain circumstances, constitute Rome Statute crimes could additionally help align the ICC’s work with one of the newer challenges facing the international community in the 21st century — thereby re-affirming the relevance of the Court in a way that may not have been previously envisioned. For states that have implemented Rome Statute crimes into their domestic criminal laws, the potential for additional deterrence could be created through the use of such laws — recognizing that such legislation could be broader in scope, as it would not need to be bound to the ICC’s definitions of crimes nor by its jurisdictional limitations. While the Rome Statute admittedly would not encompass the vast number of cyber-crimes\n ‘Cyber-operation’ is a broad term indicating the employment of cyber-capabilities aimed at achieving its objectives in and through cyber-space. This article focuses on a narrow subset of cyber-operations that are harmful or malicious, particularly ones that could involve large-scale loss of life, or damage to, or destruction of, property. The term ‘cyber-attack’ might also be used, although the author does not do so here, as that term risks conflation with an ‘attack’ under International Humanitarian Law (IHL) or an ‘armed attack’ under *jus ad bellum*.\n The expert report by the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare is a welcome addition in exploring these significant topics. See *The Council of Advisers’ Report on The Application of The Rome Statute of The International Criminal Court to Cyberwarfare*, prepared by the Permanent Mission of Liechtenstein to the United Nations (2021). Expert meetings of the Council of Advisers were hosted by the Permanent Mission of the Principality of Liechtenstein to the United Nations, and co-organized by the Permanent Missions of Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Costa Rica, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Spain, and Switzerland, as well as the Global Institute for the Prevention of Aggression. The author as well as other members of the Council of Advisers contributed to the writing of the expert report, with the bulk of the writing supervised by Liechtenstein legal adviser Sina Alavi.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1135\nthat are occurring (such as data theft or extortion) — as it would only cover a limited subset of cyber-operations such as those inflicting serious loss of life or significant physical damage — the Rome Statute does have potential for use in this area. An added benefit is that such prosecutions may occur without any amendment to the Rome Statute, as at least this limited subset of cyber-operations is covered under its existing provisions.\n## 2. Background\nThe past decade or two has witnessed a significantly large number of cyber-operations in a variety of forms, including those aimed at data-theft (stealing corporate information), extortion, spreading of false information, manipulation of elections, breach of government computers in an effort to steal state secrets, as well as 'denial of service' attacks. Cyber-operations can be harmful by their nature (e.g. employing some form of malware) or because of their content (e.g. disinformation or misinformation campaigns or hate speech). Cyber-operations have sometimes proliferated beyond their originally intended targets to impacting information technology (IT) systems around the globe. To date, fortunately, cyber-operations have not resulted in widespread devastation that has caused loss of life, and, to the extent physical damage has resulted, it has been mostly to data, computer hardware and software, or, in one instance, centrifuges at a nuclear facility (the Stuxnet attack). Cyber-operations have also caused massive economic loss and compromised the personal information of millions of individuals.\nThe use of cyber-technology to date, however, makes clear that a much more catastrophic cyber-operation could occur. States are increasingly developing and utilizing cyber-weaponry as a means of warfare, and may combine cyber-weapons with conventional weapons in a 'blended attack'. Many of the\n\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nwar crimes that could be committed during a conventional armed conflict could potentially also be committed through cyber means, or by employing both cyber and conventional weapons. Outside a state of armed conflict, cyber-operations meeting the requirements of, inter alia, a widespread or systematic attack on a civilian population could fall within the ambit of ‘crimes against humanity’. Here, one need only to realize that by disabling air-traffic controls, the capability exists to cause a ‘cyber 9/11’, perpetrated, for example, by non-state actors (cyber-criminals or bands of hackers). A cyber-operation could similarly target computer systems that control critical or safety-critical infrastructure such as train traffic, nuclear facilities, hospitals, power grids, or a dam located upstream from a major city. One can imagine a long list of such targets that could be manipulated by a cyber-operation to cause serious loss of life and/or physical destruction. It is this limited subset of cyber-operations, carrying potentially grave consequences — rather than the vast number of cyber-crimes being perpetrated for pure financial gain — that this article addresses.\norganizations and companies. See Greenberg, supra note 3. The 2008 attack on Georgia was also ‘blended’. See ICC Forum, ‘New Frontiers for the ICC (International Criminal Court): Tackling Cyber Attacks through the Crime of Aggression’ (22 February 2018), available online at https://iccforum.com/forum/permalink/110/13832 (visited 30 January 2021).\n\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1137\nIdeally, state actors will develop cyber-technology, including cyber-weapons, in a responsible way, with a view to adhering to the laws of war when such weapons are utilized, such that cyber-operations — which can be precisely targeted — are directed only at military objectives and never civilian populations nor civilian or other protected objects, nor used indiscriminately or in a way that results in disproportionate ‘collateral damage’. Yet, unfortunately, not all states are committed to adhering to the laws of war and this most likely is and will be true also in the cyber-domain. (Indeed, the temptation to ignore international law could be even greater in the cyber-domain, where it is sometimes additionally difficult to identify who has launched a cyber-operation.) Furthermore, even states generally committed to complying with the laws of war rarely achieve complete compliance, as law appears particularly susceptible to violation during a state of armed conflict. Cyber-operations can also inadvertently proliferate beyond their intended target and the software code used in cyber-operations may be ‘repurposed’ by others. Concerns multiply when one considers the possibility of cyber-operations being perpetrated by (or of software used in cyber operations repurposed by) non-state actors (e.g. cyber-criminals/transnational criminal groups, terrorist organizations, loosely affiliated bands of hackers, or even isolated individuals). Such non-state actors could also be operating at the instigation or behest of a state. Cyberwarfare may in some ways ‘level the playing field’ insofar as not only powerful militaries can launch potentially destructive cyber-operations, but this is a double-edged sword. A cyber-operation could in theory be launched from one lone computer or a network of computers, making even lone hackers potentially powerful adversaries.\nUighurs may also be cyber-enabled, see infra note 149, but the ICC also lacks jurisdiction over crimes committed in China, a non-state party.\n See e.g. S.M. Mačák, ‘On the Shelf, But Close At Hand: The Contribution of Non-State Initiatives to International Cyber Law’, AJIL Unbound (2019) 81, at 82 (‘Asymmetries of cyberspace mean that the most powerful nations are, in a peculiar way, also the most vulnerable ones’); Hathaway et al., supra note 12, at 842 (‘Because it is much less costly to mount cyber-attacks than to launch conventional attacks, and because highly industrialized states are generally more dependent upon computer networks and are more vulnerable to cyber-attacks, cyber-attacks may prove to be a powerful weapon of the weak’).\n\nThis article suggests that each of the crimes in the ICC's Rome Statute — war crimes, crimes again humanity, genocide, and the crime of aggression — can be applied at least to a limited subset of cyber-operations. While a full explanation of every element of every crime is beyond the scope of this article, the author will set forth some initial observations on the characteristics of cyber-operations which might amount to Rome Statute crimes, while acknowledging some limiting factors. Specifically, Part 3 below considers five initial overarching considerations relevant to all Rome Statute crimes: (1) which cyber-operations might meet the Rome Statute's 'gravity' threshold; (2) the need to prove attribution through admissible evidence that could satisfy the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt; (3) questions of jurisdiction; (4) the Rome Statute's 'intent' requirement; and (5) the prohibition on expanding the definition of crimes by analogy. Part 4 then provides an overview of how certain cyber-operations could fall within the Rome Statute's substantive crimes.\n## 3. Overarching Considerations\n### A. Which Cyber-operations Would Satisfy the ICC's Gravity Threshold?\nAn initial key area for consideration is what kinds of cyber-operations could satisfy the gravity threshold of the Rome Statute. In order to be 'admissible', Article 17 of the Rome Statute requires that a case must be of 'sufficient gravity to justify ... action by the Court'. Additionally, Article 53 states that the Prosecutor may only initiate an investigation or proceed with a case if that case 'would be admissible under Article 17'.\nA recent Appeals Chamber decision explains the gravity requirement:\n[T]he gravity requirement ... aims at excluding those rather unusual cases where the specific facts of a given case technically qualify as crimes under the jurisdiction of the Court, but are nonetheless not of sufficient gravity to justify further action by the Court. ... '[T]he purpose of article 17(1)(d) of the Statute is not to oblige the Court to choose only the most serious cases, but merely to oblige it not to prosecute cases of marginal gravity'. ...\n[T]he Pre-Trial Chamber ... held that when determining whether the gravity requirement ... is fulfilled, both quantitative and qualitative criteria are relevant considerations. [T]he Appeals Chamber agrees with this approach.\nGiven the multitude of cyber-crimes that would not reach the Rome Statute's gravity threshold, and the significant number of cyber-operations that also might not do so, it becomes important to analyse which cyber-operations could reach that threshold. A useful starting point is found in the work of a group of independent experts who, convened at the invitation of the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence based in Tallinn, Estonia, produced two manuals. The first, referred to as 'Tallinn 1.0', addresses international law applicable to cyber-warfare. The second, convened by a more diverse group of experts and referred to as 'Tallinn 2.0', addresses cyber-operations more broadly, both during and outside armed conflict. The Tallinn Manuals are extremely important in making clear that international law (including IHL, international human rights law, and jus ad bellum) applies in the area of cyber-operations. Although the Manuals are not binding law on the ICC (nor elsewhere), and states and experts hold divergent views on the weight to accord to them, at minimum, they provide a useful starting point for analysis.\nWhile the Tallinn experts opined on international law more broadly (addressing neither the ICC nor its gravity threshold), one topic they discussed was when a cyber-operation would qualify as a ‘use of force’. (That language is of course significant in analysing when Article 2(4) of the UN Charter is violated.) Specifically, they opined that a cyber-operation constitutes a ‘use of force’ when it has ‘scale and effects’ similar to a physical/kinetic attack. Thus, the Tallinn Manual 2.0 takes the position that ‘acts that injure or kill persons or physically damage or destroy objects’ would amount to ‘uses of force’. The experts additionally suggested various criteria that ‘States are likely to consider’ as to when a cyber-operation constitutes a ‘use of force’, including: severity, immediacy, directness, invasiveness, and measurability of effects. While admittedly formulated for a different purpose, this definition is nonetheless helpful for considering which cyber-operations might reach the ICC’s gravity threshold and these criteria appear useful ones for the ICC Prosecutor to consider in making the assessment. Roscini, ‘Gravity in the Statute of the International Criminal Court and Cyber Conduct that Constitutes, Instigates or\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1141\nIt is worth noting that even loss of life (if there are a limited number of fatalities) would not necessarily reach the ICC's gravity threshold. For example, in the ICC's Comoros situation, where 10 fatalities resulted from Israeli Defense Forces firing on a ship carrying humanitarian aid bound for the Gaza strip, the ICC's Office of the Prosecutor (OTP) took the position that the fatalities did not reach the ICC's gravity threshold. On the other hand, the OTP did proceed in the Abu Garda case regarding the killing of 12 peacekeepers 'because of the significance of the target and impact on peacekeeping operations'. Reading these cases together cannot furnish a conclusion on the number of fatalities needed to reach the gravity threshold, as there are clearly additional factors that go into the analysis. Note that when the ICC Prosecutor considered the impact on peacekeeping operations as part of the gravity analysis in the Abu Garda case, she opened the door to considering, as part of the gravity analysis, the importance of pursuing a cyber-operations case — both to demonstrate the ability of the ICC to pursue such cases and potentially to increase the possibility of deterrence against future malicious cyber-operations. Likewise, a moderate amount of physical damage or destruction of objects may not meet the gravity threshold, although an exception might arise if a specially protected object were targeted. For discussion of a cyber-operation targeting hospitals in Ukraine, see text accompanying note 116 infra.\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nthe gravity threshold for cyber-operations that satisfy the Rome Statute’s gravity requirement.\nThe Tallinn experts additionally considered what would constitute an ‘armed attack’ in the cyber-domain. (That language is of course significant as a cyber ‘armed attack’ may trigger the right to individual or collective-self-defence under Article 51 of the UN Charter — self-defence that presumably could be conducted through cyber-operations, physical/kinetic operations, or both.) Specifically, the Tallinn experts relied on the ruling of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Nicaragua case that an ‘armed attack’ is a ‘particularly serious’ form of the ‘use of force’. They concluded that ‘a cyber operation that seriously injures or kills a number of persons or that causes significant damage to, or destruction of, property would satisfy the scale and effects requirement’ and thus constitute an ‘armed attack’. This provides a definition that might better approximate what the ICC’s gravity threshold should be when considering cyber-operations.\nAt the same time, it is useful to consider whether one should fully close the door to cyber-operations that do not satisfy the Tallinn Manual’s definitions (of either ‘use of force’ or ‘armed attack’) from reaching the Rome Statute’s gravity threshold. For instance, France has suggested that operations that penetrate military systems to weaken French defensive capabilities, even if this does not produce physical effects, would constitute a ‘use of force’. While France is not taking the view that such conduct would constitute a Rome Statute crime, it is worth considering whether it would reach Rome Statute gravity (assuming the elements of a Rome Statute crime could be demonstrated). The Tallinn Manual has been heavily criticized for omitting denial of service (DDoS) attacks and destruction of data under the purview of 'use of force';[47] yet, even if they were considered 'use of force', that still would not answer the question whether they should rise to the level of Rome Statute gravity. What about deaths that only remotely ensue but are connected by the chain of causation? What about causing a global shipping conglomerate and a number of other companies around the world to lose or need to shut down all IT functions in a massive malware attack that causes extensive economic loss?[48] What if this happened in conjunction with the destruction of terabytes of data of governmental organizations and companies, from media outlets to railway firms, followed by widespread power outages?[49]\nThese questions will require far more extensive consideration. The ICC's cases, to date, have focused on more 'traditional' areas.[50] Possibly, in the future, the OTP might want to consider issuing a policy paper on gravity and cyber-operations, or on cyber-operations and the Rome Statute. For present purposes, the author will suggest that it may be a helpful start to adopt the Tallinn Manual's definition of an 'armed attack' as a starting point for when a cyber-operation could satisfy the Rome Statute's gravity threshold.[51] That is, a cyber-operation that causes serious injuries or loss of life and/or significant physical damage or destruction is one that could satisfy the Rome Statute's gravity threshold. Another area that will require further consideration is whether destruction of data should be included.[52] This author has suggested a more conservative approach in that only physical damage or\n\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1145\ndestruction would reach the ICC's gravity threshold, but it is possible that destruction of data, in certain circumstances, should be included.\nAny circumstances in which the ICC were to pursue a case concerning a cyber-operation of sufficient gravity would be significant in itself — and would make clear that the Rome Statute does encompass certain cyber-operations (even if they are a very limited subset of all such operations). This ‘expressivist’ approach — pursuing prosecutions that further protected values and thereby sending a message to achieve a given result — is indeed an important and legitimate aspect of prosecutorial strategy. For example, Matthew Cross writes:\nIncreasing attention is generally being paid to the ‘expressivist’ function of international criminal law, which places emphasis on the significance of criminal prosecution and punishment as symbolising the legal and moral condemnation of the constituents of international criminal law (the international community, victims, etc). On this view, while most international or hybrid tribunals may not be in a position to deliver the ‘quantity’ of justice required for purposes such as retribution or deterrence, they can provide ‘quality’ justice which assists local and global communities in: establishing that certain forms of conduct actually take place; stigmatising that conduct; identifying the norms which proscribe that conduct; and so on.\nGravity considerations, however, provide only the initial starting point for analysis. For example, in analyzing war crimes, if there is a cyber-operation during armed conflict (either international or non-international) that also caused serious loss of life of armed combatants or destruction of military targets, these generally would not constitute Rome Statute crimes, so would not be relevant to the gravity analysis even if a war crime appeared otherwise to have\n See e.g. K. Mačák, ‘Military Objectives 2.0: The Case for Interpreting Computer Data as Objects under International Humanitarian Law’, 48 Israel Law Review (2015) 55; J. Horowitz, ‘Cyber Operations under International Humanitarian Law: Perspectives from the ICRC’, 24 ASIL Insights (19 May 2020) (data includes ‘[m]edical data, biometric data, social security data, tax records, bank accounts, companies’ client files, or electronic lists and records’). Horowitz notes that ‘[d]eleting, restricting, or tampering with essential civilian data can quickly bring government services and private businesses to a complete standstill’, and that the ICRC views ‘civilian data’ as ‘civilian objects’ for IHL purposes. Compare Art. 8(2)(b)(ii) ICCSt. (war crime of attacks on civilian objects during international armed conflict), with Art. 8(2)(e) ICCSt. (lacking the same during non-international armed conflict).\n See Roscini, supra note 33, at 271 (‘the Prosecutor might decide to select certain situations and cases involving the commission, instigation or facilitation of international crimes through cyber conduct because of their impact or to deter them in the future, even if they resulted in a lower number of victims than in other cases’); OTP Policy Paper on Case Selection and Prioritization, supra note 21, § 50(d) (listing under case prioritization criteria ‘the impact of investigations and prosecutions on ongoing criminality and/or their contribution to the prevention of crimes’).\n M.E. Cross, ‘Strategising International Prosecutions: How Might the Work of the Kosovo Specialist Prosecutor’s Office Come to Be Judged?’ 20 International Criminal Law Review (2020) 43, at 67–68 (emphasis in original).\n Even when targeting a military adversary or objective, however, the means are not unlimited. See Biller and Schmitt, supra note 52, at 188 (‘A long-standing IHL rule prohibits the employment of “weapons, projectiles and material and methods of warfare of a nature to cause superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering”, citing Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and Relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts, 8 June 1977, Art. 35(2)).\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\noccurred. Alternatively, a cyber-operation (or a physical/kinetic attack) by itself may not necessarily trigger a state of ‘armed conflict’, so then one would not meet the contextual requirement for war crimes at all. Similarly, while a limited number of fatalities, or even no fatalities, could theoretically constitute the crime of genocide if the special mental state requirement of genocide (dolus specialis) were established, in the situations of genocide that have been prosecuted to date before international criminal tribunals the number of fatalities has been considerable; thus, charging genocide absent significant fatalities could prove a risky prosecutorial strategy. As to crimes against humanity, if a single target is involved, with a limited number of victims, one may not have an attack that is ‘widespread’ or ‘systematic.’ Furthermore, as to the crime of aggression, the jurisdictional limitations appear to be so restrictive that it may be difficult to satisfy jurisdiction (absent Security Council referral) even if the ‘gravity’ threshold were met.\n## B. Proving Attribution through Admissible Evidence that Establishes Proof Beyond a Reasonable Doubt\nAn additional limiting factor (relevant for all ICC crimes) would be that all the elements of the crime would need to be proven through admissible evidence that could eventually satisfy the requirement at trial of proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Lower standards apply at the ICC for opening an investigation, issuing a warrant, and for confirmation of charges — but those standards would not apply at trial, where ultimately proof is required beyond a\n See Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, 9 December 1948, 78 UNTS 277, Art. III (including ‘[c]onspiracy to commit genocide’, ‘[d]irect and public incitement to commit genocide’, and ‘[a]ttempt to commit genocide’). See J.D. Ohlin, ‘Attempt, Conspiracy, and Incitement to Commit Genocide’, Cornell Law Faculty Publications, Paper 24 (2009) (inchoate offenses).\n The crimes in 1994 in Rwanda were adjudicated in multiple decisions of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda to constitute genocide, and the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) has likewise held in numerous decisions that the Srebrenica massacre constituted genocide. The Iraqi High Tribunal (while not an international tribunal) held that the crimes committed during the 1988 Iraqi ‘Anfal campaign’ against the Iraqi Kurds constituted genocide. See J. Trahan, ‘A Critical Guide to the Iraqi High Tribunal’s Anfal Judgment: Genocide against the Kurds’, 30 Michigan Journal of International Law (2009) 305. The suspected genocides in Darfur, Myanmar, and of the Yazidis and Uighurshave not yet been adjudicated. The ICTY to date has also rejected the theory that genocide occurred in the ‘municipalities’ — locations in Bosnia aside from Srebrenica. See e.g. Judgment, Karadžić (IT-95-5/18-T), Trial Chamber, 24 March 2016 (acquittal on charges related to genocide in the municipalities).\n See infra notes 80–84 and accompanying text.\n Art. 15ter ICCSt.\n Art. 66(3) ICCSt. For discussion of attribution, see e.g. H. Dederer and T. Singer, ‘Adverse Cyber Operations: Causality, Attribution, Evidence, and Due Diligence’, 95 International Law Studies (2019) 430.\n Art. 15(4) ICCSt.\n Art. 58(1)-(3) ICCSt.\n Art. 61 ICCSt.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1147\nreasonable doubt. This includes the issue of attribution (who conducted the cyber-operation), tracking it back not just to a state (or non-state actor/hacker group working for the state), but potentially to a particular ‘computer … to identify the person who operated the computer, and more importantly to identify the real mastermind’ behind the attack.[65]\nAttribution may be a challenge for all crimes, but particularly so for conduct in cyberspace. Not only do cyber-attackers sometimes go to considerable lengths to conceal cyber-operations,[66] states have at times deliberately hidden their cyber-operations as perpetrated by another state ('false-flagging'). This, for example, happened when 'Russian hackers piggy-backed on an Iranian cyber-espionage operation', thereby reportedly hacking into 'government and industry organizations in dozens of countries while masquerading as attackers from the Islamic Republic [of Iran].[67] Or states can hide behind non-state actors to mask their operations.[68] Even when that is not the case, cyber-operations can be difficult to attribute because they can be perpetrated through a single computer or network of computers located far from where the consequences impact, and also can be concealed by feigning that operating systems are functioning normally.[69] Furthermore, if attribution is to be made, this raises questions as to who would be in a position to do so. Will it be practical for the ICC to do this by itself? And, if not, what are the implications of relying on state cooperation in this regard?\nFor Rome Statute purposes, proof of attribution would need to be demonstrated through admissible evidence[70] and this will require authentication; moreover, simply assembling a cyber-case would be extremely complex. There would need to be evidence gathering[71] (on both the IT and operational technology (OT) sides), chain of custody would need to be established, and, furthermore, the victim might believe the issue is just a glitch in the system\n\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nrather than immediately recognize they have been subjected to an 'attack'. The OTP would need to develop significant technical expertise as would, eventually, Chambers, Defense counsel, and other participants in the ICC judicial process. This knowledge could be internally developed through hiring and/or the use of outside experts; yet, all of this might be very difficult to organize without excellent state cooperation. The more that cyber investigatory capacities of the ICC increase, the more important will it be for the court to have in place protections safeguarding privacy and related digital rights; the ICC will thus need (and probably should already have) a privacy policy and data protection standards that are binding on the institution.72\n## C. Issues of Jurisdiction\nWhile questions of jurisdiction merit a far more extensive analysis, it is worth initially observing that a cyber-operation may often be launched from one state (the 'attacker' state), where the operations originated, with consequences (or 'effects')73 felt in one or more (even many) 'victim' states. Absent a Security Council referral, either the 'attacker' state or 'victim' state would need to be a state party to the Rome Statute, or the perpetrators would need to be nationals of a state party — because the Rome Statute gives the ICC jurisdiction over the nationals of, and crimes committed on the territory of, states parties.74 In this latter regard, the Pre-Trial Chamber's ruling in the Myanmar/Bangladesh situation holds that at least one element of the crime must have been committed on the territory of a state party for ICC jurisdiction to exist.75\nWhere many states are impacted, the question arises whether even a modest amount of impact (effects) in one ICC state party would suffice to give the ICC jurisdiction, or whether some kind of threshold must be satisfied — and, if so, whether this threshold may be satisfied collectively if multiple states are affected, and whether they would all have to be ICC states parties? For example, if the attack produces consequences in ten states but only one is an ICC state party, would that suffice to create jurisdiction if the effects in the one state party do not independently satisfy the threshold but the effects in the ten states would do so? The preliminary answer from the ICC appears to be in the affirmative. In the Comoros situation, the Pre-Trial Chamber confirmed its view\n\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1149\nthat conduct occurring outside the jurisdictional reach of the Court may be taken into account for the purpose of gravity analysis. The OTP agrees with this and has proposed the test that such extra-jurisdictional conduct must be ‘rationally and adequately’ linked to the crimes that are within the jurisdiction of the Court in order to be taken into account.\nThere is also the question of the transit of an attack through the servers of a third state party or multiple third states parties (also referred to as the ‘routing state(s)’). The Tallinn experts (while opining on jurisdiction more generally and not ICC jurisdiction) suggested that in such a situation there would be only a ‘minimal connection with cyber infrastructure on that state’s territory’. The Tallinn experts differentiated a situation where cyber infrastructure in the third state is taken over, which they conclude could create jurisdiction because the ‘use of such compromised cyber infrastructure [would not be] de minimis’. If the ICC were to take an analogous approach, use of cyber infrastructure in a third state that is an ICC state party potentially could create ICC jurisdiction, although mere transit through the servers of a third state party might not do so.\nThe crime of aggression has a different and more complex jurisdictional regime. Crimes committed by non-state party nationals or on the territory of a non-state party are completely excluded from ICC jurisdiction. As to states parties, it depends on how one reads the Kampala amendment and the Activating Resolution that activated crime of aggression jurisdiction. The possibility of referral by the UN Security Council also exists, covering all four crimes, and provides another route whereby jurisdiction may be created.\n## D. The ‘Intent’ Requirement and Unintended Consequences\nGiven that several cyber-operations to date have proliferated well-beyond their intended targets, another question is whether the Rome Statute would have any applicability for unintended results; here, one might consider both (1) unintended and foreseeable consequences, and (2) unintended and unforeseeable consequences. These issues were considered by the Tallinn experts in terms of responsibility more generally (not in the Rome Statute context). The Rome Statute appears to take a fairly restrictive approach with its requirements of ‘intent’ and ‘knowledge’ in Article 30. Article 30(2) specifies that ‘intent’ exists when (1) a ‘person means to engage in the conduct’ or (2) ‘is aware that [the consequences] will occur in the ordinary course of events’. ‘Knowledge’ is defined as awareness that a ‘circumstance exists’ or ‘a consequence will occur in the ordinary course of events’. While there is some support for including notions such as conscious risk-taking or recklessness, the ‘leading view in the early practice of the ICC’ takes a ‘restrictive interpretation’. Thus, ‘[t]he Lubanga appeal judgment confirmed the interpretation put forward in the Bemba decision on the confirmation of charges, that under Article 30 … “the standard for the foreseeability of events is virtual certainty”’.\n United Nations Treaty Collection, Ch. XVIII, Penal Matters, ‘Amendments on the Crime of Aggression to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court’, as of 18 January 2021, available online at https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XVIII-10-b&amp;chapter=18⟨=en (visited 30 January 2021).\n See Arts 13(b), 15ter ICCSt. For background on Security Council referrals and the crime of aggression, see J. Trahan, ‘Revisiting the Role of the Security Council Regarding the International Criminal Court’s Crime of Aggression’, 17 Journal of International Criminal Justice (2019) 471.\n See supra note 7 (Ukraine).\n See Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 343, §§ 13–14 (considering reasonably foreseeable consequences versus unexpected results).\n Art. 30(2)(a)-(b) ICCSt.\n Art. 30(3) ICCSt.\n Case Matrix Network, Art. 30(2)(b), Intent in Relation to Result (Mohamed Elewa Badar and Sara Porro, authors) updated 18 August 2017.\n Ibid. (citing Judgment on the Appeal of Mr. Thomas Lubanga Dyilo Against His Conviction, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-A-5), Appeals Chamber, 1 December 2014, § 441 et seq; Decision Pursuant to Article 61(7)(a) and (b) of the Rome Statute on the Charges of the Prosecutor Against Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo, Bemba (ICC-01/05-01/08-424), Pre-Trial Chamber, 15 June 2009, § 359 et seq). Other cases also endorse this ‘virtual certainty’ standard: see Judgment, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-3121-Red A5), Appeals Chamber, 1 December 2014, § 447; Judgment Pursuant to Article 74 of the Statute, Katanga (ICC-01/04-01/07-3436), Trial Chamber II, 7 March 2014, §§ 776–777.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1151\nIf ICC jurisprudence remains consistent with that approach, responsibility would not attach to unforeseeable consequences, and even as to foreseeable consequences, the threshold would be quite high — ‘virtual certainty’ that the consequences will result. For example, imagine a dam above a city is penetrated and water released flooding a city below the dam. Under the Lubanga/Bemba standard, responsibility would only attach for flooding the city if there were ‘virtual certainty’ of that consequence. (By contrast, the ad hoc tribunals found there was responsibility for ‘reasonably foreseeable’ crimes when applying ‘joint criminal enterprise’ (type 3).) While a strong argument can be made that recklessness should sometimes rise to the level of intent (and some older ICC Pre-Trial decisions take that approach), it does not seem to be the ICC’s primary approach, nor does the ICC appear to adopt the standard of ‘reasonable foreseeability’. ‘Intentional endangerment’ arguably should, however, create individual criminal responsibility and the ICC’s states parties might consider a Rome Statute amendment to expressly encompass it as satisfying the intent requirement. Note also that domestic courts, as mentioned, as well as other international or hybrid tribunals are not limited by the Rome Statute’s standards — so the Rome Statute’s failure to encompass ‘recklessness’ does not mean that it is displaced in international criminal law more generally. Thus, the requirements in Article 30 of ‘intent’ and ‘knowledge’ could prove an additional limiting factor, excluding criminal responsibility for unforeseeable results and setting a high standard as to foreseeable results, requiring ‘virtual certainty’ of the consequences.\n## E. In case of ambiguity, the definition shall be interpreted in favour of the person being investigated, prosecuted or convicted'. Thus, one would either need to 'fit' the cyber-operation in question into the Statute's existing structure or not. Arguing about the similarities between a physical/kinetic attack and a cyber-operation, for example, may not suffice, because it would be suggesting application by analogy. This limitation and the presumption that ambiguity favours the defendant, however, does not mean that one could not give an updated, modern reading to Rome Statute provisions. Law, to serve a useful purpose, should meet contemporary challenges. Furthermore, the Rome Statute is generally 'weapons neutral' or 'technology neutral' — one applies the crimes regardless of the particular weapon or technology utilized; viewed in this light, cyber is simply akin to a new weapon or technology system.\nThus, the above discussion suggests the potentially applicability of the Rome Statute to a limited subset of cyber-operations (1) if they meet the Rome Statute's gravity threshold; (2) where attribution could be proven, eventually, beyond a reasonable doubt; (3) where jurisdiction exists; (4) where 'intent' can be demonstrated (which appears to exclude responsibility for unforeseen consequences and limit responsibility even for foreseen consequences); and (5) where the harm caused falls within the definition of a Rome Statute crime without drawing upon analogies, with ambiguity construed to favour the defence.\n# 4. Consideration of the Rome Statute's Substantive Crimes\nThe next section briefly overviews how the Rome Statute's four crimes might apply to certain cyber-operations, and outlines the key elements of each. The author does not suggest this is a comprehensive discussion; rather, this overview clarifies that at least a limited subset of cyber-operations could fall within the ambit of the Rome Statute's crimes.\n# A. Cyber-Operations as War Crimes under the Rome Statute\nAs mentioned, the Tallinn Manual 2.0 takes as its starting point that a cyber-operation can constitute a use of force. The Tallinn Manuals further take the view that, in a state of armed conflict (whether international armed conflict or non-international armed conflict), all the rules of international humanitarian law apply in the cyber-domain. The ICJ’s holding in the Nuclear Weapons case reinforces this as the court maintained that IHL applies to ‘all forms of warfare and to all kinds of weapons’. Cyber-operations may be employed during and in the context of an already existing armed conflict or they (either alone or in conjunction with conventional weapons) might, in theory, create the state of armed conflict. If cyber-operations are subject to IHL, then, for example, they may not target civilians or be targeted indiscriminately (both of which would violate the principle of distinction), and may not cause excessive ‘collateral damage’ (which would violate the principle of proportionality). See further Rowe, supra note 13 (‘Exacerbating the dangers of collateral damage is the increasing similarity of the software on military and civilian computers’; ‘even if a military site is accurately targeted by a cyber-attack, its damage may spread to civilian sites through electronic mail, shared storage media, web sites, or shared network infrastructure’).\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\namount to war crimes and thus give rise to individual criminal responsibility under international law'.\nUnder the Rome Statute, ‘[the] Court [has] jurisdiction in respect of war crimes in particular when committed as a part of a plan or policy or as part of a large-scale commission of such crimes.’ Thus, there is no absolute requirement to prove a ‘plan or policy’, or that the crimes are ‘large-scale’, although such instances would ‘in particular’ be of relevance to the Court. Additionally, for a war crimes case, all the contextual elements would need to be proven — such as the existence of an ‘armed conflict’ (whether international or non-international), a ‘nexus’ between the cyber-operation and the armed conflict, and the awareness of the perpetrator of the factual circumstances that established the existence of the armed conflict. There would also be a need to prove the elements of the specific underlying war crime, as well as the need to prove attribution (linking a specific perpetrator sufficient to satisfy individual or superior responsibility), the need to establish intent and knowledge, and the need to satisfy jurisdiction.\nAs to the armed conflict requirement, under the generally accepted definition from the Tadić case, ‘an armed conflict exists whenever there is a resort to armed force between States or protracted armed violence between governmental authorities and organized armed groups or between such groups within a State’. The Rome Statute (and IHL) particularly exclude ‘situations of internal disturbances and tensions, such as riots, isolated and sporadic acts of violence or other acts of a similar nature’. For non-international armed conflict, the operations must have reached a minimum level of intensity and a non-state armed group must have achieved a certain level of organization. Decision on the\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1155\norganizational requirements, such that cyber-operations alone may not always establish the existence of a non-international armed conflict.\nThe cyber-attacks on Eastern Ukraine provide a possible example of war crimes conducted using, at least partly, cyber-operations. These attacks were ‘blended attacks’, perpetrated through cyber and physical/kinetic means. The armed conflict there has killed more than 10,000 people, and, in addition to conventional military bombardments, included hacking into dozens of governmental organizations and companies through a ‘scorched-earth’ cyber-attack that affected victims ranging from media outlets, to railway firms and hospitals, causing hundreds of thousands of homes to lose electricity and shutting down at least three regional utilities. Both the United States and the UK take the view that the cyber-attacks on Ukraine were perpetrated by Russia’s military intelligence service, commonly known by the Russian acronym GRU. Such cyber-operations conducted during a state of armed conflict could, if all the elements of the crimes were proven, potentially constitute the war crime of intentionally directing attacks against the civilian population, or launching a disproportionate attack, wherein incidental loss of life or injury to civilians is ‘clearly excessive in relationship to the concrete and direct overall military advantage anticipated’. The cyber-operations also appear to have been ‘indiscriminate’. A cyber-operation against a medical facility could also constitute a war crime under Rome Statute Articles 8(2)(b)(xxiv) or (e)(ii). Of course, one would need to be able to attribute responsibility to particular individuals for an ICC case to proceed and this could prove difficult.\nConfirmation of Charges, Lubanga (ICC-01/04-01/06-803-tEN), Pre-Trial Chamber I, 29 January 2007, § 233.\n See Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 385 (‘given the threshold of violence and the degree of organization of the armed groups that is required for a non-international armed conflict … cyber operations in and of themselves will only in exceptional cases amount to a non-international armed conflict’). The Rome Statute lists the use of indiscriminate weapons as a war crime in Article 8(2)(b)(xx), but states that this applies only to weapons ‘included in an annex to this Statute’; yet, there is no annex. A cyber-operation could be used in an indiscriminate fashion, or, to the extent that a cyber-weapon has the capability to self-replicate and mutate, it might be argued that (like a biological weapon) it has become ‘inherently indiscriminate’ such that it is incapable of being targeted. States parties should either amend the Rome Statute to create the required annex or delete the requirement of having an annex; they should additionally amend the Rome Statute to include the war crime (with a completed annex or no annex requirement) if committed during non-international armed conflict.\n## B. Cyber-operations as Crimes against Humanity under the Rome Statute\nThe hallmark requirements for crimes against humanity are acts ‘committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack directed against any civilian population, with knowledge of the attack’. Article 7(2)(a) defines the ‘attack’ against the civilian population as ‘a course of conduct involving the multiple commission of acts [enumerated in Article 7(1)] against any civilian population, pursuant to or in furtherance of a State or organizational policy to commit such attack’. The ‘attack’ needed to prove ‘crimes against humanity’ need not be a military attack; in fact, the hallmark of crimes against humanity is that the attack is directed against a civilian population and need not be linked to armed conflict. Cyber-operations as Genocide under the Rome Statute\nIn the same way that a cyber-operation that targets persons in particular protected groups could constitute the crime against humanity of persecution, genocide is a crime that targets members of a distinct ‘national, ethnical, racial or religious group’. As to the crime of genocide, it is not the attack itself, but the intent behind the attack that is the crux of the crime. Thus, for the *dolus specialis* (special mental state requirement) of genocide to be satisfied, there must be proof of: (1) ‘intent to destroy’, (2) ‘in whole or in part’, (3) a ‘national ethnical, racial or religious group’, (4) ‘as such’ (i.e. because individuals belong to such a group). The Tallinn Manual explains how and when a cyber-operation could qualify as an ‘armed attack’, and this could potentially satisfy that definition, particularly if the cyber-operation is committed by the armed forces of a state. One would additionally need to attribute responsibility to a particular leader (or head of cyber command) ‘in a position effectively to exercise control over or to direct the political or military actions of a State’, who planned, prepared, initiated, or played a role in the execution of the cyber-operation. Potentially, as mentioned, the leader could have employed non-state actors (hacker groups) to carry out the operation if their acts are attributable to, or adopted by, the state. The cyber-operation would need to constitute a ‘manifest’ violation of the UN Charter, excluding an operation that is de minimis (insufficient in gravity and/or scale) and/or unclear in terms of its legality/illegality. Yet, because of seemingly extensive jurisdictional limitations — if they are valid — it could be quite difficult to trigger ICC jurisdiction, absent Security Council referral. Here, the specific (and restrictive) jurisdictional regime regarding the crime of aggression (lex specialis) probably overrides the general ICC case law (issued in the context of jurisdiction as to genocide, crimes against humanity, and war crimes) according to which only one element of the crime need to have occurred on the territory of a state party in order to create jurisdiction (lex generalis).\n See supra notes 80-85 and accompanying text (jurisdiction for crime of aggression).\n Art. 8bis(2)(d), ICCSt.\n Art. 8bis(2)(b), ICCSt. (emphasis added).\n See K.L. See supra note 32 and accompanying text (severity, immediacy, etc.).\n See supra notes 80-84 and accompanying text.\n See Trahan, supra note 44.\n See Bangladesh/Myanmar Decision, supra note 75 and accompanying text. Thus, for example, as to the crime of aggression, even if one element of the crime occurred on the territory of an ICC state party (e.g. at NATO headquarters in Belgium), that would not create jurisdiction over the actions of nationals of a non-state party at NATO headquarters, because the general Rome Statute rules on jurisdiction would be displaced by the more specific regime regarding\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1163\nAgain returning to the example of cyber-election interference, and considering it in terms of the crime of aggression, election interference certainly could be considered an attack against ‘sovereignty’, covered by Article 8bis(2). Yet, it is questionable whether the interference rises to the level of a ‘manifest’ Charter violation, required by Article 8bis(1). Furthermore, regardless of whether all other elements of the crime could be met, at least one state alleged to be significantly involved in election interference, the Russian Federation, is not a state party to the Rome Statute, so there would be no ICC jurisdiction over the crime of aggression by Russian nationals whether committed on the territory of the United States or within the territories of other Rome Statute states parties. Again, the author’s analysis does not imply there should be no ramifications for such election interference. It should also be recalled that national legislation implementing the crime of aggression could omit the ‘manifest’ requirement and would not be restricted by the Rome Statute’s jurisdictional limitations, so could still encompass election interference as the crime of aggression or in some other manner.\n# 5. Conclusion\nThis article has only touched the surface of what will need to be a far more extensive study of how the crimes in the ICC’s Rome Statute could potentially encompass cyber-operations. Much has been written by cyber experts on the application of the laws of war to cyber operations and on how IHL violations can create war crimes exposure; that body of writing alone clearly suggests the Rome Statute’s potential applicability. As mentioned, an expert report by the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare will contribute further to exploring these important topics.\nWhile the ICC’s cases to date have primarily concerned atrocity crimes committed in less economically developed areas, a role for the Court in addressing even a limited subset of cyber-operations might help to reinforce\nthe crime of aggression, which provides there is no jurisdiction regarding the nationals of non-states parties. See Art. 15bis(5), ICCSt.\n See e.g. S.J. Schakelford, ‘The Law of Cyber Peace’, 18 Chicago Journal of International Law (2017) 11 (quoting the Nicaragua case, supra note 39 (as a matter of sovereignty, nations have an obligation not to interfere in one another’s domestic affairs if that intervention relates to ‘the choice of a political, economic, social, and cultural system’); Efrony and Shany, supra note 3, at 640 (discussing how cyber-operations can violate sovereignty); Tallinn 2.0, supra note 24, at 17 (‘Rule 4: A State must not conduct cyber operations that violate the sovereignty of another State’).\n See Efrony and Shany, supra note 3, at 609–617 (discussing cyber election interference by the Russian Federation).\n Art. 15bis(5) ICCSt.\n See supra note 2.\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nits relevance for states with developed economies — all of which (along with states with developing economies) are experiencing an enormous number of cyber-attacks. Accordingly, various states parties to the Rome Statute may welcome the recognition that certain cyber-operations could constitute Rome Statute crimes, and support the ICC’s addressing of such cases.\nOf course, the author sincerely hopes that cyber-operations will never result in fatalities or large-scale physical destruction. Yet, to try to increase potential deterrence of such harmful events, it is important to make clear that the ICC could prosecute certain cyber-operations meeting the legal requirements of the Rome Statute, including gravity. Communicating this by the ICC, and/or pursuing cases that fall within that limited subset, could be important in conveying that states may not achieve through cyber means what would be Rome Statute crimes if committed through kinetic/conventional means — a risk that increases as technology continues to develop.\n While developed states parties should be ‘willing’ and ‘able’ to use their courts to prosecute cyber-operations, which would render an ICC case ‘inadmissible’, it will depend if the domestic laws of the particular state: (1) encompass the particular conduct at issue, and (2) reach the conduct to the extent it occurred abroad — with perpetrators and victims potentially in many countries. Thus, the totality of the crime might not be ‘able’ to be prosecuted within the domestic courts of any one state party, potentially rendering the case ‘admissible’ before the ICC. States parties that have implemented Rome Statute crimes into their domestic criminal codes thereby have at least certain cyber-operations criminalized, but not all states parties have enacted implementing legislation.\n As mentioned above, arguably, none of the cyber-operations to date has yet reached the threshold that is probably required by the Rome Statute — with the possible exception of those in Ukraine and the potentially cyber-enabled genocides in Myanmar and against the Uighurs. But see supra note 75 (concerning the jurisdictional principle in the Bangladesh/Myanmar Decision).\n Because there hopefully will be few, if any, cyber-operations rising to the level of Rome Statute gravity and satisfying the elements of the crimes, the ICC’s docket should not be significantly impacted.",

          "preceding_text": "ored through cyber technology,",
          "footnote": "One could imagine infiltrating people's genetic/medical information — collected by doctors, hospitals, insurance companies, or governments — for members of the genocidal group to use to identify and attack members of the protected group.       "flat_text": "SYMPOSIUM\nAPPLICATION OF ICL TO INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES, IN PARTICULAR TO CYBER-OPERATIONS\n# The Criminalization of Cyber-operations Under the Rome Statute\nJennifer Trahan*\n# Abstract\nThis article examines how a cyber-operation that has consequences similar to a kinetic or physical attack — causing serious loss of life or physical damage — could be encompassed within the crimes prosecuted before the International Criminal Court (ICC). It explains when and how such a cyber-operation could fall within the ambit of the ICC's crimes — genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression. The article additionally acknowledges some limitations as to which cyber-operations would be encompassed, given the ICC's gravity threshold as well as the potential difficulty of attributing conduct to a particular suspect through admissible evidence that could meet the requirement of proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Notwithstanding such limitations, increased awareness of the previously largely overlooked potential of the Rome Statute to cover certain cyber-operations could potentially contribute to deterring such crimes.\n* Clinical Professor, NYU Center for Global Affairs, USA. The author greatly benefitted from attending meetings of the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare, convened by the Permanent Mission of Liechtenstein to the United Nations, on which she was privileged to serve. See note 2. She also thanks Pano Yannakogeorgos for aiding her understanding of cyber-operations. The author appreciates being able to discuss the article at workshops sponsored by the Ostrom Workshop Program on Cybersecurity and Internet Governance at Indiana University, and at the 2020 International Criminal Court Scholars' Forum. She particularly appreciates the comments of her respective discussants Asaf Lubin and Elies van Sliedregt, as well as the comments and edits of Matthew Cross. Erin Lovall, Kara McDonald, and Samantha Wynne provided research assistance. A shorter version of this article, more focused on deterrence, will appear in S. Shackleford, F. Douzet, and C. Ankersen (eds), Cyber Peace: Charting a Path Toward a Sustainable, Stable, and Secure CyberSpace (forthcoming, Cambridge University Press, 2022). [jt487@nyu.edu]\nJournal of International Criminal Justice 19 (2021), 1133–1164\n© The Author(s) (2021). Published by Oxford University Press. All rights reserved.\nFor permissions, please email: journals.permissions@oup.com\nhttps://doi.org/10.1093/jicj/mqab066 Advance Access publication 8 November 2021\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\n# 1. Introduction\nThis article examines how a cyber-operation (an activity enabled by conduct in cyberspace) that has consequences similar to a kinetic or physical attack (causing serious loss of life or physical damage) could be encompassed within the crimes that may be prosecuted by the International Criminal Court (ICC). While this article is a conversation starter and does not contain a comprehensive discussion of all the elements of the crimes, or all potential cyber-operations that might fit within their ambit, it provides an overview of when and how a cyber-operation could constitute genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, or the crime of aggression. It includes the potential for prosecuting both state actors (e.g. those within cyber-command structures, armed forces, or intelligence agencies) and non-state actors (cyber-criminals or informal bands of hackers). Additionally, the article acknowledges some of the limitations on the prosecution of cyber-operations, such as the Rome Statute’s gravity threshold as well as the potential difficulty of attributing conduct to a particular suspect through admissible evidence that could, at trial, met the threshold of proof beyond reasonable doubt. Notwithstanding these limitations, increased awareness of the potential of the Rome Statute to encompass certain cyber-operations could contribute to deterring the commission of crimes by these means, as would actual prosecution(s) by the ICC, were the necessary requirements met.\nRecognition that cyber-operations can, in certain circumstances, constitute Rome Statute crimes could additionally help align the ICC’s work with one of the newer challenges facing the international community in the 21st century — thereby re-affirming the relevance of the Court in a way that may not have been previously envisioned. For states that have implemented Rome Statute crimes into their domestic criminal laws, the potential for additional deterrence could be created through the use of such laws — recognizing that such legislation could be broader in scope, as it would not need to be bound to the ICC’s definitions of crimes nor by its jurisdictional limitations. While the Rome Statute admittedly would not encompass the vast number of cyber-crimes\n ‘Cyber-operation’ is a broad term indicating the employment of cyber-capabilities aimed at achieving its objectives in and through cyber-space. This article focuses on a narrow subset of cyber-operations that are harmful or malicious, particularly ones that could involve large-scale loss of life, or damage to, or destruction of, property. The term ‘cyber-attack’ might also be used, although the author does not do so here, as that term risks conflation with an ‘attack’ under International Humanitarian Law (IHL) or an ‘armed attack’ under *jus ad bellum*.\n The expert report by the Council of Advisers on the Application of the Rome Statute to Cyberwarfare is a welcome addition in exploring these significant topics. See *The Council of Advisers’ Report on The Application of The Rome Statute of The International Criminal Court to Cyberwarfare*, prepared by the Permanent Mission of Liechtenstein to the United Nations (2021). Expert meetings of the Council of Advisers were hosted by the Permanent Mission of the Principality of Liechtenstein to the United Nations, and co-organized by the Permanent Missions of Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Costa Rica, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Spain, and Switzerland, as well as the Global Institute for the Prevention of Aggression. The author as well as other members of the Council of Advisers contributed to the writing of the expert report, with the bulk of the writing supervised by Liechtenstein legal adviser Sina Alavi.\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1135\nthat are occurring (such as data theft or extortion) — as it would only cover a limited subset of cyber-operations such as those inflicting serious loss of life or significant physical damage — the Rome Statute does have potential for use in this area. An added benefit is that such prosecutions may occur without any amendment to the Rome Statute, as at least this limited subset of cyber-operations is covered under its existing provisions.\n## 2. Background\nThe past decade or two has witnessed a significantly large number of cyber-operations in a variety of forms, including those aimed at data-theft (stealing corporate information), extortion, spreading of false information, manipulation of elections, breach of government computers in an effort to steal state secrets, as well as 'denial of service' attacks. Cyber-operations can be harmful by their nature (e.g. employing some form of malware) or because of their content (e.g. disinformation or misinformation campaigns or hate speech). Cyber-operations have sometimes proliferated beyond their originally intended targets to impacting information technology (IT) systems around the globe. To date, fortunately, cyber-operations have not resulted in widespread devastation that has caused loss of life, and, to the extent physical damage has resulted, it has been mostly to data, computer hardware and software, or, in one instance, centrifuges at a nuclear facility (the Stuxnet attack). Cyber-operations have also caused massive economic loss and compromised the personal information of millions of individuals.\nThe use of cyber-technology to date, however, makes clear that a much more catastrophic cyber-operation could occur. States are increasingly developing and utilizing cyber-weaponry as a means of warfare, and may combine cyber-weapons with conventional weapons in a 'blended attack'. Many of the\n\nJICJ (2021) 1133-1164\nwar crimes that could be committed during a conventional armed conflict could potentially also be committed through cyber means, or by employing both cyber and conventional weapons. Outside a state of armed conflict, cyber-operations meeting the requirements of, inter alia, a widespread or systematic attack on a civilian population could fall within the ambit of ‘crimes against humanity’. Here, one need only to realize that by disabling air-traffic controls, the capability exists to cause a ‘cyber 9/11’, perpetrated, for example, by non-state actors (cyber-criminals or bands of hackers). A cyber-operation could similarly target computer systems that control critical or safety-critical infrastructure such as train traffic, nuclear facilities, hospitals, power grids, or a dam located upstream from a major city. One can imagine a long list of such targets that could be manipulated by a cyber-operation to cause serious loss of life and/or physical destruction. It is this limited subset of cyber-operations, carrying potentially grave consequences — rather than the vast number of cyber-crimes being perpetrated for pure financial gain — that this article addresses.\norganizations and companies. See Greenberg, supra note 3. The 2008 attack on Georgia was also ‘blended’. See ICC Forum, ‘New Frontiers for the ICC (International Criminal Court): Tackling Cyber Attacks through the Crime of Aggression’ (22 February 2018), available online at https://iccforum.com/forum/permalink/110/13832 (visited 30 January 2021).\n\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1137\nIdeally, state actors will develop cyber-technology, including cyber-weapons, in a responsible way, with a view to adhering to the laws of war when such weapons are utilized, such that cyber-operations — which can be precisely targeted — are directed only at military objectives and never civilian populations nor civilian or other protected objects, nor used indiscriminately or in a way that results in disproportionate ‘collateral damage’. Yet, unfortunately, not all states are committed to adhering to the laws of war and this most likely is and will be true also in the cyber-domain. (Indeed, the temptation to ignore international law could be even greater in the cyber-domain, where it is sometimes additionally difficult to identify who has launched a cyber-operation.) Furthermore, even states generally committed to complying with the laws of war rarely achieve complete compliance, as law appears particularly susceptible to violation during a state of armed conflict. Cyber-operations can also inadvertently proliferate beyond their intended target and the software code used in cyber-operations may be ‘repurposed’ by others. Concerns multiply when one considers the possibility of cyber-operations being perpetrated by (or of software used in cyber operations repurposed by) non-state actors (e.g. cyber-criminals/transnational criminal groups, terrorist organizations, loosely affiliated bands of hackers, or even isolated individuals). Such non-state actors could also be operating at the instigation or behest of a state. Cyberwarfare may in some ways ‘level the playing field’ insofar as not only powerful militaries can launch potentially destructive cyber-operations, but this is a double-edged sword. A cyber-operation could in theory be launched from one lone computer or a network of computers, making even lone hackers potentially powerful adversaries.\nUighurs may also be cyber-enabled, see infra note 149, but the ICC also lacks jurisdiction over crimes committed in China, a non-state party.\n See e.g. S.M. Bellovin, S. Landau, and H.S. Lin, ‘Limiting the Undesired Impact of Cyber Weapons: Technical Requirements and Policy Implications’, 3 Journal of Cybersecurity (2017) 59; N.C. (difficulties of attribution).\n This occurred with the NotPetya attack.\n States can design cyber-weapons to reduce proliferation risks and to reduce the ability of others to ‘repurpose’ cyber-weapons: Bellovin et al., supra note 13, at 60.\n See e.g. J. Mačák, ‘On the Shelf, But Close At Hand: The Contribution of Non-State Initiatives to International Cyber Law’, AJIL Unbound (2019) 81, at 82 (‘Asymmetries of cyberspace mean that the most powerful nations are, in a peculiar way, also the most vulnerable ones’); Hathaway et al., supra note 12, at 842 (‘Because it is much less costly to mount cyber-attacks than to launch conventional attacks, and because highly industrialized states are generally more dependent upon computer networks and are more vulnerable to cyber-attacks, cyber-attacks may prove to be a powerful weapon of the weak’).\n\nThis article suggests that each of the crimes in the ICC's Rome Statute — war crimes, crimes again humanity, genocide, and the crime of aggression — can be applied at least to a limited subset of cyber-operations. While a full explanation of every element of every crime is beyond the scope of this article, the author will set forth some initial observations on the characteristics of cyber-operations which might amount to Rome Statute crimes, while acknowledging some limiting factors. Specifically, Part 3 below considers five initial overarching considerations relevant to all Rome Statute crimes: (1) which cyber-operations might meet the Rome Statute's 'gravity' threshold; (2) the need to prove attribution through admissible evidence that could satisfy the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt; (3) questions of jurisdiction; (4) the Rome Statute's 'intent' requirement; and (5) the prohibition on expanding the definition of crimes by analogy. Part 4 then provides an overview of how certain cyber-operations could fall within the Rome Statute's substantive crimes.\n## 3. Overarching Considerations\n### A. Which Cyber-operations Would Satisfy the ICC's Gravity Threshold?\nAn initial key area for consideration is what kinds of cyber-operations could satisfy the gravity threshold of the Rome Statute. In order to be 'admissible', Article 17 of the Rome Statute requires that a case must be of 'sufficient gravity to justify ... action by the Court'. Additionally, Article 53 states that the Prosecutor may only initiate an investigation or proceed with a case if that case 'would be admissible under Article 17'.\nA recent Appeals Chamber decision explains the gravity requirement:\n[T]he gravity requirement ... aims at excluding those rather unusual cases where the specific facts of a given case technically qualify as crimes under the jurisdiction of the Court, but are nonetheless not of sufficient gravity to justify further action by the Court. ... '[T]he purpose of article 17(1)(d) of the Statute is not to oblige the Court to choose only the most serious cases, but merely to oblige it not to prosecute cases of marginal gravity'. ...\n[T]he Pre-Trial Chamber ... held that when determining whether the gravity requirement ... is fulfilled, both quantitative and qualitative criteria are relevant considerations. [T]he Appeals Chamber agrees with this approach.\nGiven the multitude of cyber-crimes that would not reach the Rome Statute's gravity threshold, and the significant number of cyber-operations that also might not do so, it becomes important to analyse which cyber-operations could reach that threshold. A useful starting point is found in the work of a group of independent experts who, convened at the invitation of the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence based in Tallinn, Estonia, produced two manuals. The first, referred to as 'Tallinn 1.0', addresses international law applicable to cyber-warfare. The second, convened by a more diverse group of experts and referred to as 'Tallinn 2.0', addresses cyber-operations more broadly, both during and outside armed conflict. The Tallinn Manuals are extremely important in making clear that international law (including IHL, international human rights law, and jus ad bellum) applies in the area of cyber-operations. Although the Manuals are not binding law on the ICC (nor elsewhere), and states and experts hold divergent views on the weight to accord to them, at minimum, they provide a useful starting point for analysis.\nWhile the Tallinn experts opined on international law more broadly (addressing neither the ICC nor its gravity threshold), one topic they discussed was when a cyber-operation would qualify as a ‘use of force’. (That language is of course significant in analysing when Article 2(4) of the UN Charter is violated.) Specifically, they opined that a cyber-operation constitutes a ‘use of force’ when it has ‘scale and effects’ similar to a physical/kinetic attack. Thus, the Tallinn Manual 2.0 takes the position that ‘acts that injure or kill persons or physically damage or destroy objects’ would amount to ‘uses of force’. The experts additionally suggested various criteria that ‘States are likely to consider’ as to when a cyber-operation constitutes a ‘use of force’, including: severity, immediacy, directness, invasiveness, and measurability of effects. While admittedly formulated for a different purpose, this definition is nonetheless helpful for considering which cyber-operations might reach the ICC’s gravity threshold and these criteria appear useful ones for the ICC Prosecutor to consider in making the assessment. For example, in the ICC's Comoros situation, where 10 fatalities resulted from Israeli Defense Forces firing on a ship carrying humanitarian aid bound for the Gaza strip, the ICC's Office of the Prosecutor (OTP) took the position that the fatalities did not reach the ICC's gravity threshold. Likewise, a moderate amount of physical damage or destruction of objects may not meet the gravity threshold, although an exception might arise if a specially protected object were targeted. Specifically, the Tallinn experts relied on the ruling of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Nicaragua case that an ‘armed attack’ is a ‘particularly serious’ form of the ‘use of force’. While France is not taking the view that such conduct would constitute a Rome Statute crime, it is worth considering whether it would reach Rome Statute gravity (assuming the elements of a Rome Statute crime could be demonstrated). The Tallinn Manual has been heavily criticized for omitting denial of service (DDoS) attacks and destruction of data under the purview of 'use of force';[47] yet, even if they were considered 'use of force', that still would not answer the question whether they should rise to the level of Rome Statute gravity. What about deaths that only remotely ensue but are connected by the chain of causation? What about causing a global shipping conglomerate and a number of other companies around the world to lose or need to shut down all IT functions in a massive malware attack that causes extensive economic loss?[48] What if this happened in conjunction with the destruction of terabytes of data of governmental organizations and companies, from media outlets to railway firms, followed by widespread power outages?[49]\nThese questions will require far more extensive consideration. The ICC's cases, to date, have focused on more 'traditional' areas.[50] Possibly, in the future, the OTP might want to consider issuing a policy paper on gravity and cyber-operations, or on cyber-operations and the Rome Statute. For present purposes, the author will suggest that it may be a helpful start to adopt the Tallinn Manual's definition of an 'armed attack' as a starting point for when a cyber-operation could satisfy the Rome Statute's gravity threshold.[51] That is, a cyber-operation that causes serious injuries or loss of life and/or significant physical damage or destruction is one that could satisfy the Rome Statute's gravity threshold. Another area that will require further consideration is whether destruction of data should be included.[52] This author has suggested a more conservative approach in that only physical damage or\n\nCyber-operations under the Rome Statute 1145\ndestruction would reach the ICC's gravity threshold, but it is possible that destruction of data, in certain circumstances, should be included.\nAny circumstances in which the ICC were to pursue a case concerning a cyber-operation of sufficient gravity would be significant in itself — and would make clear that the Rome Statute does encompass certain cyber-operations (even if they are a very limited subset of all such operations). This ‘expressivist’ approach — pursuing prosecutions that further protected values and thereby sending a message to achieve a given result — is indeed an important and legitimate aspect of prosecutorial strategy. For example, Matthew Cross writes:\nIncreasing attention is generally being paid to the ‘expressivist’ function of international criminal law, which places emphasis on the significance of criminal prosecution and punishment as symbolising the legal and moral condemnation of the constituents of international criminal law (the international community, victims, etc). On this view, while most international or hybrid tribunals may not be in a position to deliver the ‘quantity’ of justice required for purposes such as retribution or deterrence, they can provide ‘quality’ justice which assists local and global communities in: establishing that certain forms of conduct actually take place; stigmatising that conduct; identifying the norms which proscribe that conduct; and so on.\nGravity considerations, however, provide only the initial starting point for analysis. Alternatively, a cyber-operation (or a physical/kinetic attack) by itself may not necessarily trigger a state of ‘armed conflict’, so then one would not meet the contextual requirement for war crimes at all. Similarly, while a limited number of fatalities, or even no fatalities, could theoretically constitute the crime of genocide if the special mental state requirement of genocide (dolus specialis) were established, in the situations of genocide that have been prosecuted to date before international criminal tribunals the number of fatalities has been considerable; thus, charging genocide absent significant fatalities could prove a risky prosecutorial strategy. As to crimes against humanity, if a single target is involved, with a limited number of victims, one may not have an attack that is ‘widespread’ or ‘systematic.’ Furthermore, as to the crime of aggression, the jurisdictional limitations appear to be so restrictive that it may be difficult to satisfy jurisdiction (absent Security Council referral) even if the ‘gravity’ threshold were met.\n## B. Proving Attribution through Admissible Evidence that Establishes Proof Beyond a Reasonable Doubt\nAn additional limiting factor (relevant for all ICC crimes) would be that all the elements of the crime would need to be proven through admissible evidence that could eventually satisfy the requirement at trial of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
